story:
Synopsis

"American Boy" is a short film with a giant story. Alex is only ten, so he knows squat about the hostile world he was born into. Mom's off working all day because she's a pay check away from eviction. Dad's locked up because he's a brown skinned man who fell into all the wrong traps. Alex's older brother, Juan, is on the same trajectory, too young to realize he's just another pawn for a trillion dollar drug cartel. 

Our film takes place the day it all comes crashing down on Alex. The question is, will he get back up?

 

Why support this campaign?

1. We will endeavor to make a powerful film, to the highest cinematic standards.

2. This is a story that Hollywood avoids, perhaps because it's painful to think about children murdering other children. And we're not talking boy soldiers in Sudan or Somalia - but youngsters all over the US, who are also caught up in a war they didn't create. By providing real context, this film goes some way to honor those we've lost - and raise awareness about those we still need to protect.

3. Some children experience a reality more terrifying than fiction. They live in a constant state of fight or flight and suffer personal loss on the scale of any epic tragedy. Our film will show that world, unvarnished, through the eyes of an utterly innocent ten year old boy.

4. The idea is based on a thousand true stories and was inspired by interviews recorded by the writer/director while filming at-risk youth moving in and out of the criminal justice system. Every young offender was once a defenseless kid, and it's illuminating to revisit that moment of innocence in context. To imagine them before things went so terribly wrong. An audience can empathize if they better understand.

 

What Is Asked For & What Will Be Returned

The goal is to raise $25,000.

No principal filmmakers will receive any funds. 

All money raised will go to cast, crew, permits, production and post production, including a live recording of a children's choir to close out the film.

Because we focus on minors, we must comply with state permit rules for children in film, including on-set teachers and shorter work days. That increases budget.

Likewise we must comply with state permit rules for use of weapons, including official police presence on location, canvassing the neighborhood before filming etc. 

Because the content includes weapons, jeopardy, escape and chase sequences, we need stunt coordinators, expert make-up and special effects artists, digital SFX programmers etc. 

Thank you for reading!

story:
Who are we
The short film "Twist d'amour" will be produced by a unit of independent filmmakers in Switzerland.  The unit comprises of a bunch of diverse artists and film lovers, all passionate about movie making.  

The objective for this new short movie is to submit to an International Film Festival.

What we need & what’s in for you
Learning from some early pilot projects, the unit feels that we still have needs to produce better quality films and would appreciate your financial support.  The financial support will all be used towards production costs, mainly: to rent additional equipment, more number of professional lights, props, craft services, add-in’s and plug-ins for Davinci Resolve and other production expense.  

We are hoping to raise $3000 to cover our additional production costs:

•    Air tickets: 500
•    Lights rent: 500
•    Extra props: 300
•    Location: 300
•    Catering: 150
•    Festival Fees: 150
•    Post Production: 1000 mainly add-in’s and plug-ins for Davinci Resolve

We are grateful each to all of you who read out our proposal and donated! 

Other Ways You Can Help
If you are unable to contribute financially to this project, sharing this page with your friends and followers is just as helpful. The more people we get to see this campaign, the higher chance we have of reaching our goal. Don't forget to share this using the Indiegogo share tools on this page!

As we produce this film, we want to create communities and a network that we would like to engage with for this project and many more to come.  


Thank you to making this dream a reality!

story:
Poverty and Homelessness statistics in Canada:

1 in 7 (or 4.9 million) people in Canada live in poverty.

21% of single mothers raise their children in Canada in poverty.

1.3 million children in Canada live in poverty, that's 1 in 5.

Niagara Falls is one of the most amazing cities in the world, right? Of course! And yet...

In Niagara alone, the number of people helped by Project Share (Niagara Falls food bank) between 2008 and the end of of 2016 rose by a shocking 26.5%. In Niagara, 1682 households were forced to rely on emergency shelter last year.

Now we are making a movie to support the Niagara Falls food bank once again and spur even more action in communities across Ontario, Canada, North America, even the world!

Every day, our list of generous sponsors grows. We are counting on you to help us shine a spotlight on Niagara and on what can be accomplished when we all work together!

This incredible story features a 100% Canadian Cast and Crew, shot entirely on location in Niagara Falls. Now that is exciting!

 

  By John Law, Niagara Falls Review (Tuesday, July 4, 2017 4:19:30 EDT PM)

In 2009, ten Niagara Falls men came together to test their endurance, their patience, and maybe their own friendship.

Five muggy days later, they had raised $302,000 for Project SHARE, and made the phrase '10 Men in a Tent' part of the local lingo. It spawned a follow-up fundraiser with most of the same participants in 2010, and a female version called 12 Women Who Care in 2011 and 2012.

The original fundraiser was sparked by Niagara Falls businessman – and now regional councillor – Bob Gale, who pitched the concept of familiar faces gathered in a tent for five days and four nights on his property next to the Gales gas station on Montrose Road. He was joined by former Niagara Falls Review publisher Dave Martineau, councillor Jim Diodati (now mayor), Ice Dogs owner Bill Burke, radio personality Rob White, Ripley's Entertainment manager Tim Parker, then Winter Festival of Lights manager Dino Fazio, Dr. George Zimakas, and businessmen Brian Pellow and Kevin Grealy.

It was an enormous success. And now, nearly a decade later, it will live on as a movie.

Martineau enjoys part-time work as an actor these days. While on the set of the TV show Reign last summer, he started talking about 10 Men in a Tent with screenwriter and director Joseph Schur. The more Martineau talked, the more Schur's eyes lit up.

“He grabbed my arm and said 'This is a movie!'”

Both Schur and Martineau were intrigued by a fictional story based on the true events, which could shed light on poverty and the need for food banks across the country. Schur soon had a script ready, and Martineau gathered the original 10 Men earlier this year to share the news.

“I filled them in and said 'This is the path we're going to go down.' I don't want to speak for anybody...there was genuine excitement, but (also) 'Yes Dave, this sounds really cute, we'll see if it happens.'

“Even my initial reaction was like, 'Come on, this is crazy.'”

And yet, every step of the way, Martineau finds more support for the project. With a budget of $150,000, he believes an IndieGoGo campaign for $50,000 will get the cameras rolling. If all goes well, filming could begin this fall or next spring.

While there are elements of humour – there was no lack of funny stuff during the original 10 Men in a Tent – it will mostly be an inspirational story told from the viewpoint of Jeff Guarasci, Project SHARE's resource development coordinator in 2009 ( and now the city's community development coordinator).

“He was the guy that organized it all, showed up every morning, kept everything on track,” says Martineau. “It's good he's going to get the recognition he should have got eight years ago.”

Fazio remembers feeling uncertain how the event would go over in 2009. Would people respond to ten well-off guys sleeping in a tent to raise money?

“From the time we walked to the site from the Project SHARE office three kilometres away, on the hottest day of the summer, I hoped we could rally the community behind us,” he recalls. “Some thought the idea was weird or strange, but the community really latched on and saw the promise of what we were trying to do.

“It was a moving experience.”

White can remember being hot, hungry and sleepless, but is “honoured to be part of this event, and the legacy of it.”

Every day of the event, businesses, residents, sports teams, etc., would drop off food or money. For five days, the tent became a focal point in the city.

Martineau, who will be the film`s executive producer, says the event wasn’t meant to simulate homelessness, but provide a “tiny glimpse into what it’s like for a lot of people.”

He looks back on it as a triumph for the community, not just the 10 Men.

“When you're that close to it, you don't realize maybe what occurred,” he says. “Maybe we didn't understand the magnitude of it, and we're kind of starting to now.”

 

We'll be announcing the cast very soon. Stay tuned for exciting updates!

 

We'll be making further announcements soon. Stay tuned for exciting updates!

"I was fortunate to have read the screenplay and I was truly moved! The story is incredible. It made me laugh and it made me cry at times. I can't wait to see this movie in the theatre!"

Therasa McLennan, Television Producer

 

Our feature film "10 Men in a Tent" is made possible by the generous support of our sponsors!

"I was fortunate to have read the screenplay and I was truly moved! The story is incredible. It made me laugh and it made me cry at times. I can't wait to see this movie in the theatre!"

story:
“All Risk No Award: The Story of Stunts” is a feature length documentary that seeks to bring attention to the deep history and connection between films and stunts.

Action is so much a part of what we expect in a modern film, that it’s hard to imagine them without it. Top studios throw billions of dollars each year at the chance of being the next big summer blockbuster. If you look at the list of the top 100 grossing films of all time, which represent over one hundred billion dollars in revenue, every last one of them contain action.

Just recently, action icon Mad Max returned with Fury Road, one of the biggest, baddest, balls out action films in years. The film smashed box office records and was nominated for an Oscar as Best Film of the Year. Oscar night was a landslide; with Mad Max taking home Oscars for costume design, makeup and hair, production design, sound and film editing. It was a celebration of all of the hard work and craftsmanship that went into the spectacle that is a blockbuster movie, well almost all of it. Despite being seen in almost every sequence shown during that night, no one from the stunt department were given the time of day.  

As strange as it may seem, the men and women who actually put their lives on the line, the people going off the buildings and getting caught on fire, are not eligible for an Oscar. Even though the trailers for the films that they are celebrating are filled with the hard work and dedication from these heroes, and even though it is their sacrifice that is really generating those million dollar box offices, they get no award.  

So why does Hollywood treat the stunt community like their dirty little secret? And who are these insane people that would still do this for a living?  

By talking with stunt industry vets, actors, and directors about the essential role that stunts play in bringing movie magic to life, we hope to get a glimpse into the mavericks and renegades that make it happen.  

The film will feature Jack Gill (Fast and Furious 5,6,7,8 and many other films and tv shows), an industry giant who has been fighting for Oscar recognition for 25 years. He has bled, broken bones, and given his life to a business that he loves. But that business does not seem to love him back. Jack has led the charge since the 90’s to get the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to recognize the stunt department’s contribution in the grand illusion. He has recently helped to form a grassroots movement called #standUPforstunts that has begun staging protests to draw attention to their cause. He has gained the support of industry heavyweights like Spielberg, Scorsese, and Schwarzenegger. Countless celebrities have started posting pictures of themselves with their stunt doubles supporting the cause. And now that Mad Max almost won best picture, it is getting harder for them to keep saying no. Now truly is a time to take action.

We plan to follow Jack and his fellow stunt professionals as they attempt once again to convince the Academy to create a “BEST ACTION DESIGNER” category for Oscars. We will watch Jack and the #standUPforstunts movement as they connect with entertainment industry professionals, including members of the Academy, and make their way through the obstacle course of Hollywood red tape.

We also plan to follow the struggles of up and coming stunt players, showing the sacrifice, practice, passion, and bravery it takes to work in this highly competitive industry. From the brutal workouts and training to the struggles supporting themselves and their families in the sporadic world of filmmaking, we plan to get beyond the glamour and glitz of showbiz facades and show the true human cost of fulfilling the public’s insatiable appetite for more action. Like everyone involved in this business, these brave souls are the dreamers who give their lives for the hope of getting to be in the big show.

Movies aren’t just made by producers or directors, it takes teams of people that give everything to do something they love. The time has come to recognize the amazing work of the dreamers, rebels, and daredevils who risk their lives so we can believe, if only for a brief moment, that maybe a person really can fly.  

We hope the film will be watched widely and broadly for both the narrative of, Jack Gill, a blockbuster movie stunt professional looking for Oscar recognition for his craft, and also for the action packed physicality of stunt work being planned and the finished product coming to life on screen. Additionally we see the film being screened in universities and in film schools across the US and abroad as Jack continues to struggle with the Academy for a stunt Oscar category.

The film would seek to explore these five main character themes.

The Activist

This character, Jack Gill, is our introduction into this world.  He is a legend of stunt craft and he has, for the past 25 years led his long standing battle against the Academy and their status quo.  We learn through him the setup, the history of stunts and his opinion on why the Oscars won’t recognize them.  We follow him to petition the Academy again and stage a protest to gain support.    

The Young and Hungry

We will explore what it takes to be a newcomer to this difficult to enter circle of professionals.  We will follow this character through their daily routine featuring their training; exercise, rituals, auditions, and rejections while they wait for their shot. What does it take to be in stunts?

The Working Stunt Player

We will explore the dues paid and injuries sustained to get to be in the big show.  We will hear the stories of their treatment on sets ranging from glowing to furious.  From stars lying about their contribution to films, to the Academy's refusal to recognize their craft in the Oscar ceremony, we will explore the misconceptions and truths behind one of the crafts most dangerous areas of work.

The Sad Stories

This character or characters would explore the reality of the business, not everyone can live that dream.  We would try and find stories of those whose dreams, whether unrealistic or unfairly realized, just haven’t turned out.  When do you say enough?

The Veterans

These characters would help us explore the discarded legends of the unseen stunt players. These stories would show the impact of what living life at full throttle has on a person's psychical and emotional landscape. These people’s lives are scarred with divorce, alcoholism, and unfulfilled expectations. Has the ride been worth it?

The Supporting Cast will be made up of famous actors, producers, and members of other categories that do get Oscars, as we explore the lunacy of not including stunts contribution to the industry.  And most of all, these characters can lend tales of bravery and respect to the dialogue and show that stunt work deserves recognition. 

And finally we wish to explore the pending extinction of the stunt department at the hands of the CG wizards of Marin County.  More and more stunt players are losing work to productions that choose their less realistic, safer, and increasingly more cost friendly avatars in the computer-generated worlds.  Soon this kind of bravado and bravery could very well be a thing of the past.  

But, much like the rise of CG effects that has marred and muddied the cinema landscape, we will find our films missing something in their absence.  They will be missing the human spirit that made this era of cinema so great. Computers can never top watching Zoe Bell hanging from the front of a 1970 Dodge Challenger in Tarantino's Death Proof. Stunt work like that will trump anything the CG wizards of Hollywood can cook up.   

Now more than ever, it is time to take ACTION. It’s time to give these amazing talents a place in the Oscars.

 

We have already begun filming and reaching out to some of the top talent in the entertainment industry to be a part of this documentary. A lot of the top stunt performers and coordinators have already signed on to the project. Here are just a few that have already agreed to be a part of this documentary.

Jack Gill

Action Designer / 2nd Unit Director

His credits go back to the late 1970’s including Fast and Furious films 5, 6, 7, 8, Bad Boys 2, Beverly Hills Cop 2, First Blood, Ride Along 2, and The Other Guys. He has been lobbying for the Academy to have a stunt category for over 25 years.

Andy Armstrong

Action Designer / 2nd Unit Director

His credits go back to the mid 1970’s including The Spy Who Loved Me, Rambo 3, Universal Soldier, Thor, and The Amazing Spider-Man 1 & 2. He recently received a Lifetime Achievement Award from the Taurus Stunt Awards.

Chad Stahelski

Director / Second Unit Director / Action Designer / Owner 87eleven Stunts

His credits include Point Break, The Matrix Trilogy, Spider-Man 2, Mr. and Mrs. Smith, 300, Iron Man 2, The Wolverine, Captain America: Civil War, and the John Wick films.

Sam Hargrave

Second Unit Director / Action Designer / Stunt Double

His credits include the upcoming Avengers: Infinity War, Atomic Blonde, The Accountant, Captain America: Civil War, The Hunger Games: Mocking Jay parts 1 & 2.

Debbie Evans

Stunt Double / Stunt Driver

Her credits include The Fast and Furious films, Jack Reacher: Never Go Back, Captain America: The Winter Soldier, The Town, Wanted.

Heidi Moneymaker

Stunt Performer / Double

Scarlett Johansson's stunt double for the Avengers and Captain America films.  Other credits include John Wick: Chapter 2, Furious 7, The Lone Ranger, Sucker Punch, Star Trek, Rambo.

Tanoai Reed

Stunt Performer / Double

Dwayne “The Rock” Johnson’s stunt double for The Other Guys, Fast and Furious 5,6,7, Pain and Gain, and many more.

Tony McFarr

Stunt Performer / Double

Chris Pratt’s stunt double for the Guardians of the Galaxy films.

Andy Dylon

Action Designer / Stunt Performer / Double

Johnny Depp’s stunt double for the Pirates of the Caribbean films.

Jessie Graff

Stunt Performer

Her credits include The Dark Knight, X-Men: First Class, Wonder Woman, Bright, American Ninja Warrior.

 

COOL STUFF!

T-Shirt Design Option #1 & Hoodie Design (Grey shirt/sweatshirt - Navy lettering)

T-Shirt Design Option #2 (Black shirt - White lettering)

*Both shirts are Unisex designs.

What you really get, other than the cool perks you pick, is to be a part of something bigger!

You'll be a part of a MOVEMENT TO CHANGE THE ACADEMY AWARDS.

We're not saying our documentary will make this change, but it will be a huge stepping stone for all of the professionals in the industry and everyone else that believes that the change needs to happen. 

 

We have a few different funding goals. Our starting goal is $150,000. The money will go to travel, legal fees, insurance, music rights, post sound, post color, IndieGoGo fees, perk costs, and of course a little pay for our sweat equity. 

Our 2nd goal would be $250,000. This would allow us to travel to another interview or two, get rights to more music for the film, and also afford us to be able to hire a couple specialty crew members (sound, camera).

Our 3rd and ultimate goal is $650,000. This is what it would take to cover all of the IndieGoGo fees and Perk costs to hit our dream budget of $500,000. At this budget we’d be able to travel to more of our interviewees (most of them live in LA, but are rarely here because the films they work on are shot outside of California). We would also be able to afford to work on this film full time for at least a year. The two previous goals would only cover enough for us to work part time, thus taking a lot longer to make the film. We want to spend all of our time on this to make the best film possible in the fastest time frame that we can.

As with all crowdfunding campaigns, the more we can raise, the more we can put into production.

Our goal is to shoot and edit in time for a big festival push for the 2019 festival season starting in January 2019. We want this film to be making some noise around Oscar season in February of 2019 as well.

 

Director/Editor/Producer GB Young, a 20 year veteran of production has recently completed editing his third feature documentary for Wild West Picture Show "Gamechangers: Dreams of BlizzCon" which will be released by FilmRise in 2018.  He also produced, co-directed, edited and shot “Prescription Thugs” which premiered at the 2015 Tribeca Film Festival and was picked up and released by Samuel Goldwyn Films and has been in iTunes top 10 documentaries for over six months. He edited the Feature Documentary “Heartland” which won awards at Kansas City Film Festival, Omaha Fest, and St. Louis International Film Festival as well as had multiple showings on PBS. GB's first documentary, “My Name is Smith”, which he shot and edited, was an official selection at the Big Sky and Austin Film Festivals in 2010. Additionally, GB is a founding member of the comedy group Generation Awesome, where he directed the internet hit “The Bartender Hates You” which has garnered over 18 million hits on YouTube and has been featured on Comedy Central’s Tosh.0, Revver, College Humor, Funnyordie, and Yahoo Comedy.

Producer Alan Stephens has over a decade of experience working in the entertainment industry. He recently produced Chris Bell's newest documentary "A Leaf of Faith" which has a distribution deal with The Orchard. He did additional cinematography on "Prescription Thugs" for Wild West Productions. It premiered at the 2015 Tribeca Film Festival and was picked up and released by Samuel Goldwyn Films. It can be seen on Netflix and has been in iTunes top 10 documentaries for over six months. He started with small jobs working on smash hit TV shows like “Big Brother” and “Hell’s Kitchen”, he quickly started learning all aspects of the industry.  He jumped between Reality TV, Film production, Scripted TV production, Music Videos, and Documentaries, all the while absorbing as much about every production as possible.  It wasn’t long after his first jobs that he started working with a few friends to create handfuls of short films for the Internet. Doing this allowed him to learn how to produce quality content on a limited budget. The most successful Internet videos he and his friends produced are “The Bartender Hates You”. The series has amassed over 18 million combined hits on YouTube and been featured on Comedy Central. Alan has also produced content for the internet site MACHINIMA, been a producer on hit TV shows like “Top Gear USA” for the History Channel. He also produced a micro budget feature film “Drugs & other Love”, a goofball buddy comedy which is in the vein of “Half Baked” and “Dumb and Dumber”. 

Director of Photography Cris Borgnine, son of the late Hollywood icon Ernest Borgnine, has been working steady in the industry learning all aspects. His credits include huge blockbuster films including “Star Trek Into Darkness”, “Battleship”, and “Mission: Impossible – Ghost Protocol”. In addition to his feature film experience he has also produced and shot a handful of documentaries, short films, and music videos.

 

Distribution and Marketing Strategy:

Upon completion, we hope to hold our world premiere at one of the major festivals in North America or Europe.

After a robust festival run, we envision the film having some limited theatrical release, but more likely finding a distribution home with one of the major doc broadcasters (HBO, Showtime, Netflix Worldwide, Hulu, CNN Films, POV or IL) in addition to international distribution with broadcasters like Arte, NDF, etc.

Our previous film “Prescription Thugs” premiered at the 2015 Tribeca Film Festival and was acquired by Samuel Goldwyn Films. We hope for a similar release plan for “All Risk No Award: The Story of Stunts”.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

WHAT!? There are more ways to help? Of course there are. We understand that not all are able to contribute. But you can still help. Spread the word! Make some noise about this! Share it on Facebook, Tweet about it, Instagram it, Snap Chat it, scream about it from roof tops, be that crazy person walking down the street talking loudly for all to hear, present this in your daily board room meeting, let everyone in the subway car that are temporarily trapped in there with you know about it. Every word of mouth situation is OK with us! Spread the word! Let's make a difference in Hollywood. 

 - https://www.facebook.com/allrisknoaward/

 - https://www.instagram.com/allrisknoaward/

 

RISKS AND CHALLENGES

The biggest challenge is distribution – "All Risk No Award: The Story of Stunts" does not have a distributor attached yet. We producers are truly doing this all ourselves. Lack of distribution can also be a blessing. Making this film without a distributor or financier can allow us to make it without them demanding we adapt the film to fit their needs.

 

THE FINE PRINT (legal stuff) 

  • You must be over 18 or accompanied by a parent or legal guardian (who will count as your plus one) to attend the LA Advance Screening.
  • Our final cut of the film may have to be further edited in certain cases to adhere to the laws in the country which it is being viewed, or for different types of media.
  • All shooting locations are subject to change for a variety of reasons, including the amount of money we are able to raise and the particular locations giving us the right to shoot.
  • This fundraising campaign is all subject to applicable IndieGoGo rules/regulations, movie guild rules and applicable law. If any of this conflicts, we will work with you in good faith to give you a substitute reward.
  • Any Producer credit perks don't include ownership rights or potential profit sharing of any kind. 

To sum it up, movie making is an insane business, with a lot of unknown factors. We start with a great idea. Then, we assemble the best team possible, get insurance, and make contingency plans. It's impossible to guarantee everything will come together exactly as planned, but in the end, we will have created a movie that hopefully all of us can be proud of. It's a great journey, and I thank you in advance if you can help make this ride possible.

FAQ

When will the movie be made?

We've already started filming! If you guys help us make the funding goal, we will be able to finish it much faster so you can see it sooner.

When will the movie be released?

Since we don’t have distribution, we don’t have a release date locked down. There are a lot of factors that whoever distributes our film will take into account when picking a date.  We would like to make a big film festival push starting in January 2019 (Sundance Film Festival). We hope to find a distributor there or soon after and release the film in a theater near you.

When will the rewards be available?

The physical items, like t-shirts should come pretty quickly. Once the campaign ends we will start working with our fulfillment center to process your perk rewards.

If the project doesn’t fund, do I get my money back?

Straight answer, no.  We chose to do the Flex funding here on IndieGoGo.  If we fail to hit our goal, depending on the amount of money we do raise, we will chose to either try and make the film on a lower budget, or use the funds as leverage to secure an investor for the remainder of the budget.  Either way, we promise to make you an excellent film that you as backers will be proud of and you will still receive your reward perks. 

Where does my money go?

All of your pledges will be collected and deposited into a bank account that my producers and I have set up for the sole purpose of funding the film.

What do you do if you exceed your goal?

Exceed our goal?  It would be amazing to even hit our goal much less exceed it.  If we are to exceed our goal (very wishful thinking) we will add the funds to the film’s budget where we feel it could use a little more. This may afford us the possibility of getting much nicer gear for shooting, book better locations, have awesome music in the film, etc..

“All Risk No Award: The Story of Stunts” is a feature length documentary that seeks to bring attention to the deep history and connection between films and stunts.
Action is so much a part of what we expect in a modern film, that it’s hard to imagine them without it. Top studios throw billions of dollars each year at the chance of being the next big summer blockbuster. If you look at the list of the top 100 grossing films of all time, which represent over one hundred billion dollars in revenue, every last one of them contain action.
Just recently, action icon Mad Max returned with Fury Road, one of the biggest, baddest, balls out action films in years. The film smashed box office records and was nominated for an Oscar as Best Film of the Year. Oscar night was a landslide; with Mad Max taking home Oscars for costume design, makeup and hair, production design, sound and film editing. It was a celebration of all of the hard work and craftsmanship that went into the spectacle that is a blockbuster movie, well almost all of it. Despite being seen in almost every sequence shown during that night, no one from the stunt department were given the time of day.  
As strange as it may seem, the men and women who actually put their lives on the line, the people going off the buildings and getting caught on fire, are not eligible for an Oscar. Even though the trailers for the films that they are celebrating are filled with the hard work and dedication from these heroes, and even though it is their sacrifice that is really generating those million dollar box offices, they get no award.  
So why does Hollywood treat the stunt community like their dirty little secret? And who are these insane people that would still do this for a living?  
By talking with stunt industry vets, actors, and directors about the essential role that stunts play in bringing movie magic to life, we hope to get a glimpse into the mavericks and renegades that make it happen.  
The film will feature Jack Gill (Fast and Furious 5,6,7,8 and many other films and tv shows), an industry giant who has been fighting for Oscar recognition for 25 years. He has bled, broken bones, and given his life to a business that he loves. But that business does not seem to love him back. Jack has led the charge since the 90’s to get the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to recognize the stunt department’s contribution in the grand illusion. He has recently helped to form a grassroots movement called #standUPforstunts that has begun staging protests to draw attention to their cause. He has gained the support of industry heavyweights like Spielberg, Scorsese, and Schwarzenegger. Countless celebrities have started posting pictures of themselves with their stunt doubles supporting the cause. And now that Mad Max almost won best picture, it is getting harder for them to keep saying no. Now truly is a time to take action.
We plan to follow Jack and his fellow stunt professionals as they attempt once again to convince the Academy to create a “BEST ACTION DESIGNER” category for Oscars. We will watch Jack and the #standUPforstunts movement as they connect with entertainment industry professionals, including members of the Academy, and make their way through the obstacle course of Hollywood red tape.
We also plan to follow the struggles of up and coming stunt players, showing the sacrifice, practice, passion, and bravery it takes to work in this highly competitive industry. From the brutal workouts and training to the struggles supporting themselves and their families in the sporadic world of filmmaking, we plan to get beyond the glamour and glitz of showbiz facades and show the true human cost of fulfilling the public’s insatiable appetite for more action. Like everyone involved in this business, these brave souls are the dreamers who give their lives for the hope of getting to be in the big show.
Movies aren’t just made by producers or directors, it takes teams of people that give everything to do something they love. The time has come to recognize the amazing work of the dreamers, rebels, and daredevils who risk their lives so we can believe, if only for a brief moment, that maybe a person really can fly.  
We hope the film will be watched widely and broadly for both the narrative of, Jack Gill, a blockbuster movie stunt professional looking for Oscar recognition for his craft, and also for the action packed physicality of stunt work being planned and the finished product coming to life on screen. Additionally we see the film being screened in universities and in film schools across the US and abroad as Jack continues to struggle with the Academy for a stunt Oscar category.

The film would seek to explore these five main character themes.
The Activist
This character, Jack Gill, is our introduction into this world.  He is a legend of stunt craft and he has, for the past 25 years led his long standing battle against the Academy and their status quo.  We learn through him the setup, the history of stunts and his opinion on why the Oscars won’t recognize them.  We follow him to petition the Academy again and stage a protest to gain support.    
The Young and Hungry
We will explore what it takes to be a newcomer to this difficult to enter circle of professionals.  We will follow this character through their daily routine featuring their training; exercise, rituals, auditions, and rejections while they wait for their shot. What does it take to be in stunts?
The Working Stunt Player
We will explore the dues paid and injuries sustained to get to be in the big show.  We will hear the stories of their treatment on sets ranging from glowing to furious.  From stars lying about their contribution to films, to the Academy's refusal to recognize their craft in the Oscar ceremony, we will explore the misconceptions and truths behind one of the crafts most dangerous areas of work.
The Sad Stories
This character or characters would explore the reality of the business, not everyone can live that dream.  We would try and find stories of those whose dreams, whether unrealistic or unfairly realized, just haven’t turned out.  When do you say enough?
The Veterans
These characters would help us explore the discarded legends of the unseen stunt players. These stories would show the impact of what living life at full throttle has on a person's psychical and emotional landscape. These people’s lives are scarred with divorce, alcoholism, and unfulfilled expectations. Has the ride been worth it?
The Supporting Cast will be made up of famous actors, producers, and members of other categories that do get Oscars, as we explore the lunacy of not including stunts contribution to the industry.  And most of all, these characters can lend tales of bravery and respect to the dialogue and show that stunt work deserves recognition. 
And finally we wish to explore the pending extinction of the stunt department at the hands of the CG wizards of Marin County.  More and more stunt players are losing work to productions that choose their less realistic, safer, and increasingly more cost friendly avatars in the computer-generated worlds.  Soon this kind of bravado and bravery could very well be a thing of the past.  
But, much like the rise of CG effects that has marred and muddied the cinema landscape, we will find our films missing something in their absence.  They will be missing the human spirit that made this era of cinema so great. Stunt work like that will trump anything the CG wizards of Hollywood can cook up.   
Now more than ever, it is time to take ACTION. It’s time to give these amazing talents a place in the Oscars.

RISKS AND CHALLENGES
The biggest challenge is distribution – "All Risk No Award: The Story of Stunts" does not have a distributor attached yet. We producers are truly doing this all ourselves. Lack of distribution can also be a blessing. Making this film without a distributor or financier can allow us to make it without them demanding we adapt the film to fit their needs.
 
THE FINE PRINT (legal stuff) 

You must be over 18 or accompanied by a parent or legal guardian (who will count as your plus one) to attend the LA Advance Screening.
Our final cut of the film may have to be further edited in certain cases to adhere to the laws in the country which it is being viewed, or for different types of media.
All shooting locations are subject to change for a variety of reasons, including the amount of money we are able to raise and the particular locations giving us the right to shoot.
This fundraising campaign is all subject to applicable IndieGoGo rules/regulations, movie guild rules and applicable law. If any of this conflicts, we will work with you in good faith to give you a substitute reward.
Any Producer credit perks don't include ownership rights or potential profit sharing of any kind. 

To sum it up, movie making is an insane business, with a lot of unknown factors. We start with a great idea. Then, we assemble the best team possible, get insurance, and make contingency plans. It's impossible to guarantee everything will come together exactly as planned, but in the end, we will have created a movie that hopefully all of us can be proud of. It's a great journey, and I thank you in advance if you can help make this ride possible.
FAQ
When will the movie be made?
We've already started filming! If you guys help us make the funding goal, we will be able to finish it much faster so you can see it sooner.
When will the movie be released?
Since we don’t have distribution, we don’t have a release date locked down. There are a lot of factors that whoever distributes our film will take into account when picking a date.  We would like to make a big film festival push starting in January 2019 (Sundance Film Festival). We hope to find a distributor there or soon after and release the film in a theater near you.
When will the rewards be available?
The physical items, like t-shirts should come pretty quickly. Once the campaign ends we will start working with our fulfillment center to process your perk rewards.
If the project doesn’t fund, do I get my money back?
Straight answer, no.  We chose to do the Flex funding here on IndieGoGo.  If we fail to hit our goal, depending on the amount of money we do raise, we will chose to either try and make the film on a lower budget, or use the funds as leverage to secure an investor for the remainder of the budget.  Either way, we promise to make you an excellent film that you as backers will be proud of and you will still receive your reward perks. 
Where does my money go?
All of your pledges will be collected and deposited into a bank account that my producers and I have set up for the sole purpose of funding the film.
What do you do if you exceed your goal?
Exceed our goal?  It would be amazing to even hit our goal much less exceed it.  If we are to exceed our goal (very wishful thinking) we will add the funds to the film’s budget where we feel it could use a little more. This may afford us the possibility of getting much nicer gear for shooting, book better locations, have awesome music in the film, etc..

story:
Help us complete the final phases of this project. We need your help for post production on this important film. Our team has been given unprecedented access to private collections, family archives and stories, objects and imagery rarely seen. We have traveled to locations in five states and nine cities to capture the history and the people associated with this remarkable story. 

About the Film:

Gustav Stickley was much more than just a furniture maker, Stickley founded perhaps the first truly American style at the turn of the 20th century. His furniture, along with his innovative ideas about materials, craft, workmanship and natural beauty combined with the ideals of pride in creation and a deeper connection to nature, were revolutionary in the early 1900’s. Yet his ideals remain relevant today. The creation of an all-encompassing lifestyle that was harmonious with nature was masterfully managed by Stickley through his seminal magazine, The Craftsman, his furniture line, his home blueprints, his New Jersey farm and his radical Manhattan retail store, which eventually led to his business’ decline and failure in the face of World War I. 

His remarkable life, the subject of many books, museum exhibitions and scholarly research over the years, has never been told on film, until now. Gustav Stickley: American Craftsman will be the definitive portrait of an amazing American icon, and this campaign will help with moving the project towards completion. With unprecedented access to private collections, family archives and top scholars on both Stickley and the arts and crafts movement, the film will take viewers deep into the world that Stickley created, and will explore the lasting legacy of his vision on the American psyche.

Stickley’s legacy is more important now than ever, thanks to the resurgence of the “maker” movement, which celebrates the handmade object and appreciation for natural materials. American ingenuity is again at the forefront of a return to the appreciation of craft and a rejection of the mass-produced, disposable object. In addition, the current farm-to-table movement has revolutionized the restaurant industry, but these same principles were utilized by Stickley when he operated the restaurant in his Manhattan building with product from his farm in New Jersey, 100 years prior. Stickley was a visionary, and an advocate for values and ideals that were long ahead of their time.

What We Need:

We need $40,000 to go toward post production work. The funds raised will go 100% towards the cost of post production including editing, image rights, etc....  We anticipate completing the editing of the film in 2018 for release.

What Happens if Our Goal is Not Reached:

We will continue to work on the film as funds become available. If we are not able to fully fund this campaign, we will be exploring other funding mechanisms such as grants . We have had great support from the Arts & Crafts community, as well as the Stickley family, and hope that you will want to be included in the list of supporters wanting to see this story on film.  

Impact of your contribution:

We hope to debut the finished film in 2018, which will be the 160th anniversary of Stickley’s birth. Our image rights and editing process will take the next 6-9 months to complete. 

We are deeply committed to telling this story on film, and will do so thanks to the support of the incredibly passionate arts and crafts community and other generous supporters. 

We Want Your Help!

We hope that you will be able to assist the project with a cash contribution, but if you are unable to there is another way to support the project, you can help spread the word to anyone you know who would be interested in our film. Gustav Stickley’s story is a true American tale of success; a first generation immigrant who followed his passion and created a unique set of ideals that envisioned a greater lifestyle, that in harmony with nature that appreciated the value and beauty of handmade items. He was a visionary who created and promoted an entire way of life and envisioned trends, that we are still enjoying today

story:
SYNOPSIS:

This 20 minutes film tells a magical surrealist story about a classical pianist. Stephan, is consumed by perfectionism in the world of music competitions and facing different expectations from his family. He comes across a female blind Asian pianist; a figment of his sub-consciousness that re-invigorates his inner being and internal universe. This awakens his full sensory abilities and intuitive intelligence of heart in the pursuit of his music.

 

WHY IS STORY IMPORTANT:

The story is relevant to us because it deals with the issues of the dichotomy between seeing the pursuit of music as a means to material and tangible gains and as a process of reinvigorating our inner being and untangling the mystery of our internal universe. It also investigates the concept of Asian philosophies including mind-body centering and its impact on our visions of the pursuit of happiness and the measurement of success.

Touching the Sound explores the concept of mind-body centering through the eyes of a competitive classical pianist and his subconscious. The methodology of mind-body centering is highly influenced by the synthesis of Eastern Philosophy and theories from Western frameworks, it is an integrated methodology that uses hands-on repatterning and movement re-education; based on physiological, anatomical, developmental, and psychophysical principles. The audience gets a glimpse of this through the non-linear and fragmented storytelling style which delve into the main character’s subconscious and memories.

Touching the Sound is a compelling art film because it delves into exploring the inter-disciplinary dialogue between narrative, live classical music and contemporary dance in the cinematic art framework. The tone of the film blends contemporary style with Eastern aesthetics that are embedded in both the cinematic language and the special effects of the film.

 

INSPIRATION:

The writer, director, and producer of this film Xiaoyin has been playing the piano since she was four. The creation of this film is inspired by her visceral experience and journey in music, and the career she embarked on before as a choreographer and her scholarly research into the fields of dance somatic and mind-body centering.  

 

WHAT WE NEED:

The film is 20 minutes long and has completed its production and the basic stages of post-production including editing. We need your help to bolster the post-production of the film. Joining us in fulfilling the visions of this film and creating the final product. Your contribution will enhance the final product through visual effects, original music, sound mixing and color correction. By doing so, the film will have a better chance of entering film festivals all around the world.  Entertainment films cost millions, but socially conscious art films written, directed and produced by women of color struggle to get funding. 

Breakdown of Post Production Costs:

 

These aspects of filmmaking are what makes the final product, enhance the storytelling, and elevate the quality and professionalism of this film. With great post-production, Touching the Sound is able to convey the true transcendental experience of creating music. All the music and dancing in this piece is completely original.

Social Media Impact

   Your contribution will make a huge difference for us, and you will get different rewards that are associated with this film as shown in the column on the right-hand side. Please also help us spread out the campaign website, Facebook official page, and Instagram, and join us in completing this film!  

Facebook page:   @touchingthesound_movie

Instagram:            @touchingthesound_2017

Production photos:

 

Meet The Team


 

 

 

Writer/Director/Producer/Editor/Actress:

Xiaoyin Zhang

Xiaoyin produced, directed and choreographed dance films and dramatic dance theatre works in London, Beijing, and Philadelphia in the past three years. These works include ’The Irretrievable Moment’ , ‘Submerged”, “内知”. ‘The Ultimate Secret of Life Cycle’. Her dance film ‘The Irretrievable Moments’ premiered in Beijing and the dance theatre version of this film premiered at Conwell Dance Theatre in Philadelphia in 2016. The film Touching the Sound is inspired by her pursuit of piano since she was four and her research into mind-body centering and dance somatic. Xiaoyin holds double Masters in MA Dance and MA Contemporary Theatre. Her inter-disciplinary trajectory between film and dance and her international background across Europe, China and the US pushes her to further delve into screenwriting and directing in the film industry.

See more of her works:  http://bit.ly/2CVyErc

Cinematographer:

Dieter Horst Baum

His unique cinematic and photographic styles have led him to collaborate with prestigious directors as a cinematographer worldwide. The shorts and feature films that he has worked on have gained a number of different awards and official selections from film festivals such as
Big Apple Film Festival ‘15, Women In Texas ‘16 and the Miami Independent Film Fest ‘16. For Touching the Sound, Dieter combined contemporary and Asian aesthetics to bring forth Xiaoyin's magical surrealist story.

Learn more about Dieter and his work here:

http://bit.ly/2p22SlI

Music Composer:

Kuan He

Based in New York, He is a Master of Music Scoring for the Film and Multimedia program at NYU. He also holds a B.A. in Recording Arts from the Communication University in China. Kaun has composed for many short films and documentaries including Road to HaiNan, which screened at the Reel China Film Festival and selected to the Sundance Film Festival.

Right now he's working on a television series entitled Magic Cooking School and composed for the feature film Cat and Peatchtopia which is currently in theaters.

Visual Effect Artist:

Sirajus Salehin

Sirajus Salehin is a New York based filmmaker. He has been professionally working in the independent film industry for over three years. Primarily working in the post-production department he worked as an Editor, Animator, and Visual Effect Artist, along with other working in other departments. He worked in a feature length stereoscopic 3D documentary, which was screened in many countries around the world, including during 2016 Cannes Film Festival in the outer circle. Working with a charismatic team of director/producer Xiaoyin Zhang, he hopes to bring his creativity and love for art into this majestic film - "Touching the Sound".

Sirajus Salehin https://sirajus.com

 

Sound Mixer:

Todd Lockwood

Todd Lockwood, based in NYC, left a career in advertising in 2015 to pursue sound editing and design as a full-time venture. His first credits followed shortly after an internship at Harbor Picture Company and independent study with award-winning professionals. Todd’s work varies from feature-length documentaries to narrative shorts and ads for TV and internet. Recently, films featuring Todd’s sound editing & design have appeared at festivals such as DOC NYC, the Awareness Film Festival, the Festival De Cine Global Dominico in The Dominican Republic, and the Vasteros Film Festival in Sweden.

Executive co-producer:

Maggi Delgado

Maggi Delgado is a 27-year-old multimedia producer from New York City. Born in the Dominican Republic, this bilingual storyteller developed a passion for film and television that lead to a BA in media studies from Hunter College. Besides creating her own content with an intersectional feminist point of view, this Latina is also a media educator who has taught media production and literacy for the public access channel of New York: MNN. While producing and hosting her podcast Mixing it Up with Maggi and writing short films, Maggi has worked as a social media manager and film festival assistant and currently, she's co-managing the crowd funding campaign for Touching the Sound with Xiaoyin.

See more of Maggi's work here:

maggidelgadomedia.com

IG: @pinkleo_productions

FB: @pinkleoproductions

story:
THE STORY

Virginia is a psychic medium working in a remote service station with the ghost of her fifteen-years-old son Tom. One night she is visited by a customer who wants to know about her deceased sister. During the tarot reading, Virginia is interrupted by unwanted memories that take her and Tom in a limbo between past and present.

Stuck in her mind, Virginia tries to save the boy but loses control and they both witness a fire destroying the service station. How much of what they saw was real?

The view of the fire stays with Tom who questions his mum and finally decides to leave. Virginia says goodbye to the boy as he vanishes in the first light of the morning. Virginia is finally visited by the customer who's still wanting to know about her sister. At last, she makes a real human connection.

WHY?

Francesco (Writer/Director)
"I moved to the UK looking for a new life. The real change started happening when I left my family behind. While writing the script, I thought about what means to change when being far away from our loved ones. I wrote the story of Virginia and Tom to find new roots where I am standing now. This is why the script is about finding new connections even when it seems too difficult to create them." 

Kayleigh  (Producer)
"When I was first presented with the script I was drawn to the strong imagery and well-developed characters. Like most of our crew, I have also experienced grief and found that Francesco has a unique way of telling this through the screen. This script is a huge challenge but it is one I wanted to undertake. This film is no doubt going to help us all develop as filmmakers and gain vital experience for our future." 

WHAT WE HAVE SO FAR

CREW

First of all we have an amazing crew that is putting all its effort in the making of the film. Soon you'll get to know them all. Watch this space!

LOCATION

While traveling in North Yorkshire, we found two fantastic locations.
A vital part of our film is the petrol station in which Virginia temporarily lives in and works from. We were lucky enough to find Willow Bridge Service Station, which we believe fits our film perfectly. Take a look!

A local farm has also given us permission to film on their land to capture our beautiful dawn and dusk shots.

The film school will provide the majority of our production equipment and will give us access to studio space for our interior shoots. They have also provided the crew with a small budget to help us achieve the film.

VISUAL EFFECTS

Oh yeah, you are probably wondering how we're going to set the service station on fire? We have a plan. Don't worry, no real fire involved! 

We are very lucky to have Emiliano Neroni, a professional CG and Visual Effects Artist on board. Due to his unique creations and talent, some of his previous work has gone viral on social media. Here is a clip from his previous work!

Emiliano is now working closely with our crew all the way from Italy to recreate a computer-generated 3D model of the service station. Using visual effects he will then set our beloved location on fire.

WHAT WE NEED

To be able to bring this story to life we need your help!
There are a lot of logistics that go into making a film and these still need to be taken care off. The budget we are hoping to raise will go towards accommodation for our cast and crew whilst filming on location, our travel, catering and help to pay for specialist crew. Your contributions will also go towards Emiliano's amazing work.

AND A BIG THANK YOU!

To say Thank You for your massive help we have some perks which include, a link to the finished film upon completion, a credit, a copy of the soundtrack and a portfolio containing exclusive photos and content from the production.

Oh... you will also have our eternal gratitude.

Cheers!

Kayleigh and the team

 

You can also follow us on Facebook

MORE NEWS TO COME!

story:
From Internationally Acclaimed Filmmakers

Comes The Guardian...

Through the eyes of GUARDIAN JACOBSON, this dramatic short film evokes the tensions we face as a people struggling to weigh the skyrocketing communal costs of health insurance against the value of individual freedom of choice and life itself.

In Jacobson’s world as an agent of Lifewatch Life & Health, the cost of ensuring the safety and health of covered individuals is near compulsory submission to the coldly calculating efficiencies of the “Controllers,” nameless and faceless actuaries with the power to decide life and death on the basis of cost / benefit analysis.

As a Guardian, it’s usually Jacobson’s job to keep insured people on track and administer warnings when they aren’t compliant with their company's Health Improvement Plan. But these days, Jacobson has taken on high paying “bonus work” in order to fund his son’s college education. In return for this extra pay, Jacobson must impose the harshest penalty an insured can endure…repossession of the insured's Biometric Neurotactic Device Implant (BNDI). Already soul-weary from his years as a Guardian, Jacobson is suddenly faced with a crisis that will force him to either relinquish everything he’s lived for or shed his last bits of his humanity.

What's a father to do?

 

Lifewatch Life & Health Wants You!

...To Get a Brain Implant!!

A source shared this upcoming commercial ad that is set to be released. In it, Lifewatch Life & Health reveals their BNDI program with a soft-sell approach intended to tug at your heart strings... but don't fall for it! Even the risks are read off in a shady whisper!!

 

 

OMG! LEAKED!

Secret Lifewatch BNDI Training Session Video.

Lifewatch's BNDI may be new to you but it's been in the works for years. We found one of the company's early training videos on how one of the early models of the device works.

 

Here's How It All Began...

Lifewatch and the BNDI may be new to you but everything that you see in The Guardian is the result of a plan that began years ago. See for yourself...

 

And now, Lifewatch proves itself to be a juggernaut that no one cares to stop. With the announcement below, Lifewatch is now officially the only government-authorized health insurer in 21 of the worlds largest nations!

 

The Cast

 

Alex B. Collins is a distinguished actor and producer, best known for his roles as "Simon Dewy" in The Accountant, "Francis" in Underground, "FBI Agent Dietrich" in 24: Legacy and "ATF Agent #1" in American Made. Collins most recently appeared as "Jack Campbell" in the TV series The Gifted.

Claire Bronson is an Atlanta-based actress, currently gracing the TV in recurring roles as Suzan Blake in Ozark. Bronson is best known for her role as "Sharon" in Nashville and her series regular roles as "Candace Stockley" in Powers, "Lindsay Savage" in Containment, "Dr. Andrea Weston" in Bloodline, the social worker in Creed  and "Evelyn Bailey" in Outcast.

The Inspiration Behind The Guardian

Kat Phillips Director Statement

Kat opens up about her personal inspiration for The Guardian and some facts behind our world that propel this project beyond just a movie. Please help us bring this cinematic vision to life and, hopefully, spark a movement.

 

Some of the best stories are those ripped from the headlines, experienced in real life or extrapolated to what could be. The Guardian was born from all three. Though the story is fictitious, the premise on which it is based is very realistic. The Guardian provides an all-to-plausible peek at the not-to-distant future of health care based on current trends in technology, insurance and politics. The film strives to leave the viewer with the questions “What if?”  and “What would I do?” lingering long after the end credits roll.

How close are we to life imitating art as will be depicted in The Guardian? REALLY CLOSE!

March 2013...Will Body Implants Be The Future of Healthcare?

2015...Chip Implanted Under The Skin Allows for Precise Real-Time Medical Monitoring

March 2018...Profusa Health Monitoring Biosensors

Wearable, Implantable Technologies

"But what about government involvement in such things," you say? Ever heard of DARPA?

Why is all this happening? One Word: Moolah...to the tune of 29% profits. YES. 29%!!! Private insurers AND the U.S. Government  are profiting! <<--True story, according to a 2017 CNBC article which says... 

..."The core business, which is providing coverage to large and mid-sized employers... and the established government programs, Medicare Advantage and Medicaid managed care, have all done well."...

Oh wait. There's more. Read it for yourself! 

 

I Have A Record Of Success!


Watch My Award-Winning Short Films...

Space Available // In the near future, the right to live will exist only when there's "space available." Therefore, only a death can make room for a new life.

 

Katrina's Wake // Katrina's Wake is the fictional story of a family who flees to their Ninth Ward attic to avoid the rising flood waters of Hurricane Katrina. No food. No water. No escape. And unfortunately, no one knows they're there.

 

The Awakening // Is it a dream or a twisted reality?

 

Producers / Production Partners

 Kat Scratch Films:  This is me, Kathilynn "Kat" Phillips. I am an Atlanta, Georgia based Writer / Director / Producer and the owner of Kat Scratch Films. Over the years, I have produced several projects. However, I'm most widely known—nationally and internationally—for my multi-award-winning films Katrina’s Wake, Chasing The White Dragon , and Space Available. Collectively, I have received 23 awards for my work as a Writer, Director and / or Producer on the projects. I'm also proud to be a Nicholl's Semi-finalist and to have had two of my films selected to be housed as part of the National Archives.

Bontrager Twins Productions: Bontrager Twins Productions is an award winning production company founded by Dewayne and Lewayne Bontrager. The company produces interactive media for organizations as well as films. Their projects have been lauded by industry professionals and fans alike. Several of Bontrager Twins Productions' projects have screened at multiple film festivals, including The Bridge, which screened at Cannes 2017.

Tanisha Coffey: Tanisha Coffey is a phenomenal Producer who has also worked as an Associate Producer, Assistant Director, Script Supervisor, Production Manager, Script Coach / Consultant or Writer on various projects. Select credits include The Other Side, Mattie: The Discovery, Test Subject B, Beautifulese, Rooney’s World and Stand Your Ground. Coffey is the owner of Sweetcoffey Productions.

Watch My Comedic Producer's Guild Short Film Neewollah!

 

Support The Guardian: Here's What We Need

The script has been written and polished. It's Sundance ready...and that's exactly what we have our sights set on! But, first things first; we need  your help to get it made!

We're currently in pre-production. Production in slated to begin June 2018.

WE'RE SEEKING DONATIONS TO COVER ESSENTIALS necessary to take this short film  script from a world imagined to a world visualized on screen...at Sundance (fingers crossed!)...such as:

(This is what we're shooting this film on! Yeah, baby!)

  • Specialized Camera Equipment To Accomplish Certain Visual Looks In The Film
  • Professional-Grade Lighting & Sound Equipment
  • Renting filming locations
  • Cast & Crew Catering (We'll be filming 5 days; each day is expected to be a 10hr day)
  • Special Effects Make-Up
  • Props
  • Liability Insurance

The Impact

Insurance companies in our country have tremendous power, which they wield at their pleasure, granting medical care, procedures, tests, treatments and medications to some while denying those same things to others with the exact same ailment. Like unspoken quotas in the workplace, the reasons for the denials are also unspoken; but if you listen to what is not said or pay close attention to the questions that go unanswered, the reasons--your age, your gender, your lifestyle, etc.--become clearer and you'll realize: You're being denied, not because you cannot be healed but because what's good for you isn't good for your insurer's bottom line. 

Too many people are in the dark about the policies and practices that big business and / or the government put in place. The Guardian, like my film award-winning short film Space Available, is meant to be a wake up call; to inspire people (to inspire YOU) to take more of an active role in what's going on around them (and YOU); to not take the freedom of choice that they (and YOU) currently have for granted...because doing so could lead to losing it all together. 

Risks & Challenges

The primary risk associated with this film project is like many others: Without sufficient funding, one of three things are most likely to happen: (a) I and the other producers will have to adjust the vision for the film to fit within the monies raised or (b) production of the movie will have to be pushed out until we can raise additional funding.

Other Ways You Can Help

We appreciate any help that you provide in bringing this project to fruition. Here are some other ways to help if a monetary donation isn't feasible or, if you want to donate as well as provide additional help:

  • If you or someone you know has resources that can help defray the costs of production, that's helpful too. For instance, if you are a restaurant or food vendor, you could donate food so we can feed our crew; if you make music, we'll need some for the film; if you have access to film equipment such as lighting packages or grip packages, we'll need that! Email us and we're happy to see how you can be involved.
  • Share, share, share! With the power of social media and your help, we can reach 2,000 willing donors. Just think, if every one gave $5, we'd meet our goal. So, please use the sharing tools here on IndieGoGo to help get the word out!

THANK YOU IN ADVANCE FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

story:
Español más abajo

Since the age of twelve, I have loved poetry and started writing songs and poems. I grew up reading Gabriel Garcia Marquez, Gabriel a Mistral, Pablo Neruda, Emily Dickinson, Paul Eluard and Maya Angelou. Poetry was part of my world and my imagination. This passion was an escape from the reality of my country Colombia that was in a constant civil war.

In my twenties, I had to live in Chile and often listened to the stories of my friends about the dictatorships and all that their families had to suffer. This touched my heart so much that I could never forget. I felt that I had to express all those emotions, experiences, and part of my memories in a film.

I want to tell a story that gives hope to people that are in all kinds of difficult situations.

I first wrote this story in 2009 after completing a writing class in New York City and have been developing it into a script since then. In 2015, after returning from Cannes Court Metrage where I showed a short film Pink Dolphin, I decided then to create a feature film with this script even though everyone around me said it was too difficult. I started shooting the film in November of 2015 and half of the shooting is complete.  And now I am here on IndieGoGo to invite you to help finish this film and to tell this wonderful story to the world.

This film is being produced independently by YV Film Production that I created with my husband Joshua R Hathaway. We were able to borrow some funds for half of the film that is complete. But because making a feature film is very expensive, we are here to invite you to be part of this film.  Every dollar raised by this campaign is going directly towards the budget of the film. ODE TO PAZ has been in development since 2015. We need the money that we’re asking for to finish this film and distribute to festivals and theatres. 100% of the money raised by this campaign will go towards making this film the best film it can possibly be.

 

Oda A Paz: Español

Desde los 12 años amé la poesía, y desde ese entonces comencé a escribir canciones y poemas. Crecí leyendo a  Gabriel García Márquez, Gabriela Mistral, Pablo Neruda, Emily Dickinson, Paul Eluard y Maya Angelou. La poesía fué parte de mi mundo y mi imaginación. Esta pasión fué un escape a la realidad de mi país Colombia, que estuvo en una constante guerra civil por muchos años.

En mis veinte, me trasladé con mi familia a vivir a Chile y frecuentemente escuchaba las historias de mis amigos chilenos sobre la dictadura y todo lo que sus familias sufrieron; ésto conmovió profundamente mi corazón y nunca lo pude olvidar.  Sentí que tenía que expresar todas esas emociones, experiencias y parte de mis recuerdos en esta película.

Quiero contar esta historia para que genere esperanza a todas las personas que están atravesando situaciones muy difíciles en sus vidas.

Escribí esta historia por primera vez en el 2009, después de terminar una clase de escritura en la ciudad de Nueva York , y he estado desarrollando el libreto desde entonces.

En el 2015 después de presentar mi cortometraje EL DELFIN ROSADO en el Festival de Cannes, decidí crear un largometraje con este libreto,  aunque muchas personas a mi alrededor dijeran que era muy difícil. Comencé a rodar  ODA A PAZ en Noviembre del 2015 y la mitad del rodaje está completo. 

Ahora estoy aquí en IndieGoGo para invitarle a ser parte de esta película y contar  esta historia a todo el mundo.

Esta película está siendo producida independientemente por la empresa YV Productora que he creado con mi esposo Joshua R. Hathaway.

Prestamos unos fondos para producir la mitad del rodaje de la película . Pero como hacer un largometraje es muy costoso, estamos aquí para invitarle a ser parte de este largometraje. Cada aporte para esta campaña va directo para el presupuesto de ésta película.

ODA A PAZ  está siendo producida desde el 2015. Necesitamos el dinero que estamos recaudando para terminar esta película y distribuirla en los festivales y teatros.  El 100% del dinero recaudado por esta campaña irá directamente a la producción de esta película,  la mejor que pueda ser realizada.
