story:
2 Days in Quito is set in one of the smaller capital cities of Latin America. Having lived here for over a year, working and exploring the city, I saw it as a unique location for me to write, direct and produce my very first feature.

Our IndieGoGo campaign is a crucial part of us getting this film up and running. Here’s how you can be part of it.

The Idea

Alone, travelling home in the back of a taxi one night (and slightly drunk), I became very aware of the silence between the taxi driver and myself. My mind wandered. My inner videogame-loving child toyed with the thought: imagine if this guy pulled a gun on me? What would drive a person to take that risk? Something premeditated? Or a totally spontaneous act? 

Travelling around in taxis is something any tourist or city native is likely to do very frequently. For several minutes or even hours, you share a space, conversing or not conversing with a stranger. Yet there’s something starkly intimate, and frankly vulnerable, about sharing that silence with one total stranger for such a time. What would it take for them to suddenly turn on me?

I ran with this idea and found myself immersed in a fantasy of a film narrative where this happens, and as I developed my story, it became deeply important to me to make this story not just about this murder -- the who, why and what of it -- but to portray it in this city, Quito, and all its intricacies and unique South American beauty. This city is rich in cultural and racial diversity as well as starkly different end to end. Modern, high-rise buildings exemplify rich areas in the North, and more modest communities showcase a completely different colonial architecture, found in the South.

I want to show a predominantly Western audience both of these parts of the city in parallel with the story about an ordinary taxi driver who, out of the blue, commits such a heinous crime in the face of sheer desperation. In parallel with us seeing all walks of life from each city's corner in his taxi, we also see our protagonist face the struggle of trying to advance himself within it in pursuit of life-long dreams. He feels trapped by the constraints of his upbringing, his job and his lack of opportunities, and the more affluent circles seem both within a hand's reach and worlds away.

About Me

My name is Jamaal Hepher, and I’ve been lucky enough to make films all over the world. I’m half Sierra-Leonean and half-English, and my travels have seen me create documentaries and shorts in England, Uganda, Tanzania, Rwanda, and Venezuela. 2 Days In Quito is the first feature film that I’ve written and will direct in Ecuador.

After living in Quito for some time with my girlfriend Emily, working for an international news company heading their video department, I decided to give myself the challenge of making this film before returning home.

Along with the huge challenge of writing a feature-length screenplay and directing the film, the whole production would put me and my team out of our comfort zones. My girlfriend and I have now left our jobs in the city to embark on this film’s production full-time, so it's a huge project to take on.

 

The Producers

Lead Producer: Ana Gabriela Yepez 

Born in Esmeraldas, Ecuador, Gabbi has worked as a producer both here and abroad for several years. Having studied Film and Television Production and Direction at IAVQ, she has taken part in international workshops and development labs such as BrLab, FicBacq, Bolivia Lab, and Cinemadamare. She has also attended some of the most important film markets such as Marché du film de Cannes, El Mercato del Filme de la Mostra in Venice, and Ventana Sur in Argentina.

Co-Producer: Emily Lyhne-Gold 

From London, United Kingdom, Emily has studied both English Literature and Film at Oxford Brookes, including screenwriting and film theory, before settling in Quito, Ecuador in June 2016. Here, she has worked as a freelance writer and has co-produced two short films, one of which won a competition and was screened in New York City at the Winter Film Festival. This will be her first time producing a feature film.

Risks and Challenges

Without your help, unfortunately, this film will not happen. The total budget is extremely low for a feature, but every penny or cent that we raise will go directly to it. Neither I nor Emily are earning a cent from your contributions. All of our funds will go directly to production costs, including catering, crew, locations, actors; making up a diverse and honest representation of Quito. We have a tight shooting schedule of 22 days.

One of the most exciting parts of this process is collaborating with local talent right here in Ecuador. All our cast and crew will be made up of a diverse representation of Quito and our script is currently being translated into Spanish. As a story unique to this city, we felt it was imperative to make use of the filmmaking community here.

 

What We Need From You

For our campaign, we are asking for $20,000 USD or roughly £15,000 GBP. It is a lot of money, but it is the minimum we need to make from the campaign.

With all independent film productions, money comes from far and wide. We have self-financed, received money from international grants, and received financing from local businesses.

The amount we are asking for from this campaign is 45% of our total budget and will ensure that we will make this film a reality. Below is a brief rundown of where the money will all go.

What You Get!

The great thing about crowdfunding is not only getting behind a project that you believe in or knowing that you were an integral part in fulfilling, but also getting a piece of whatever it is that you get to keep as your own. Below, we have listed some of the lovely things you can get depending on what you can contribute.

Note: We’ll be holding premieres both in Quito and London, so please make sure you specify which one you’re able to attend.

  • Digital Download of the Film
  • BluRay/DVD Copy of the Film
  • Premiere Tickets (either London or Quito)
  • Afterparty Tickets
  • Name in Credits
  • The Making Of Limited Edition Book
  • Signed Copy of The Script
  • Ecuadorian Meal Out In London
  • Secret Goodiebag from Ecuador
  • Physical Poster of the Film (27" x 40")

  • Associate Producer/Executive Producer credit

 

How You Can Help

During pre-production, production and post, we are going to have an active presence on social media, so you guys can see what is happening throughout the whole filmmaking process!

Please please please do your best to share with friends, family and anyone you think might be interested. Spreading the word by sharing on Facebook goes a lot further than you might think! 

To follow our progress and production updates, please like and follow our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram pages.

                                             

 

AND TO FINISH...

THANK YOU, THANK YOU, THANK YOU!
story_txt:
2 Days in Quito is set in one of the smaller capital cities of Latin America. Having lived here for over a year, working and exploring the city, I saw it as a unique location for me to write, direct and produce my very first feature.Our IndieGoGo campaign is a crucial part of us getting this film up and running. Here’s how you can be part of it.The IdeaAlone, travelling home in the back of a taxi one night (and slightly drunk), I became very aware of the silence between the taxi driver and myself. My mind wandered. My inner videogame-loving child toyed with the thought: imagine if this guy pulled a gun on me? What would drive a person to take that risk? Something premeditated? Or a totally spontaneous act? Travelling around in taxis is something any tourist or city native is likely to do very frequently. For several minutes or even hours, you share a space, conversing or not conversing with a stranger. Yet there’s something starkly intimate, and frankly vulnerable, about sharing that silence with one total stranger for such a time. What would it take for them to suddenly turn on me?I ran with this idea and found myself immersed in a fantasy of a film narrative where this happens, and as I developed my story, it became deeply important to me to make this story not just about this murder -- the who, why and what of it -- but to portray it in this city, Quito, and all its intricacies and unique South American beauty. This city is rich in cultural and racial diversity as well as starkly different end to end. Modern, high-rise buildings exemplify rich areas in the North, and more modest communities showcase a completely different colonial architecture, found in the South.I want to show a predominantly Western audience both of these parts of the city in parallel with the story about an ordinary taxi driver who, out of the blue, commits such a heinous crime in the face of sheer desperation. In parallel with us seeing all walks of life from each city's corner in his taxi, we also see our protagonist face the struggle of trying to advance himself within it in pursuit of life-long dreams. He feels trapped by the constraints of his upbringing, his job and his lack of opportunities, and the more affluent circles seem both within a hand's reach and worlds away.About MeMy name is Jamaal Hepher, and I’ve been lucky enough to make films all over the world. I’m half Sierra-Leonean and half-English, and my travels have seen me create documentaries and shorts in England, Uganda, Tanzania, Rwanda, and Venezuela. 2 Days In Quito is the first feature film that I’ve written and will direct in Ecuador.After living in Quito for some time with my girlfriend Emily, working for an international news company heading their video department, I decided to give myself the challenge of making this film before returning home.Along with the huge challenge of writing a feature-length screenplay and directing the film, the whole production would put me and my team out of our comfort zones. My girlfriend and I have now left our jobs in the city to embark on this film’s production full-time, so it's a huge project to take on. The ProducersLead Producer: Ana Gabriela Yepez Born in Esmeraldas, Ecuador, Gabbi has worked as a producer both here and abroad for several years. Having studied Film and Television Production and Direction at IAVQ, she has taken part in international workshops and development labs such as BrLab, FicBacq, Bolivia Lab, and Cinemadamare. She has also attended some of the most important film markets such as Marché du film de Cannes, El Mercato del Filme de la Mostra in Venice, and Ventana Sur in Argentina.Co-Producer: Emily Lyhne-Gold From London, United Kingdom, Emily has studied both English Literature and Film at Oxford Brookes, including screenwriting and film theory, before settling in Quito, Ecuador in June 2016. Here, she has worked as a freelance writer and has co-produced two short films, one of which won a competition and was screened in New York City at the Winter Film Festival. This will be her first time producing a feature film.Risks and ChallengesWithout your help, unfortunately, this film will not happen. The total budget is extremely low for a feature, but every penny or cent that we raise will go directly to it. Neither I nor Emily are earning a cent from your contributions. All of our funds will go directly to production costs, including catering, crew, locations, actors; making up a diverse and honest representation of Quito. We have a tight shooting schedule of 22 days.One of the most exciting parts of this process is collaborating with local talent right here in Ecuador. All our cast and crew will be made up of a diverse representation of Quito and our script is currently being translated into Spanish. As a story unique to this city, we felt it was imperative to make use of the filmmaking community here. What We Need From YouFor our campaign, we are asking for $20,000 USD or roughly £15,000 GBP. It is a lot of money, but it is the minimum we need to make from the campaign.With all independent film productions, money comes from far and wide. We have self-financed, received money from international grants, and received financing from local businesses.The amount we are asking for from this campaign is 45% of our total budget and will ensure that we will make this film a reality. Below is a brief rundown of where the money will all go.What You Get!The great thing about crowdfunding is not only getting behind a project that you believe in or knowing that you were an integral part in fulfilling, but also getting a piece of whatever it is that you get to keep as your own. Below, we have listed some of the lovely things you can get depending on what you can contribute.Note: We’ll be holding premieres both in Quito and London, so please make sure you specify which one you’re able to attend.
Digital Download of the Film
BluRay/DVD Copy of the Film
Premiere Tickets (either London or Quito)
Afterparty Tickets
Name in Credits

Signed Copy of The Script
Ecuadorian Meal Out In London
Secret Goodiebag from Ecuador
Physical Poster of the Film (27" x 40")
Associate Producer/Executive Producer credit

story:
Short Summary

When young Bruce’s world is turned upside down after witnessing the death of his parents on the streets of his Home city - he leaves his late parent's multi billion dollar company to seek out expert training in the martial arts so that one day he might return to his now crime-riddled city and cleanse it of all from th-

Hang on. 
That’s Batman. 
Most people know the story of Batman. But when Mark finds himself at a dinner party with a mysterious man named Bruce, who’s parents were murdered in front of him, who trained at a martial arts retreat, and who works night shifts - Mark’s certain that this is the real deal. Thats Batman right? Unfortunately nobody else seems to have the foggiest idea what he’s on about...

 

 

The Team

 

We are a small, close knit team. Everyone involved has a background in television, theatre and film, and a real passion for producing high quality content. With Paul Westbrook (Working Holiday, Jim O'Brien: Exorcist) directing, Reuben Meltzer producing and Cassten Roberts behind the camera, we are excited to produce an incredibly funny and original short film.

 

The Cast

 

Mark Bonanno as Mark

Seb Muirhead as Bruce

Seon Williams as Charlotte

Kaori Maeda-Judge as Rachel

Max Gettler as Robert

 

What We Need & What You Get 

We are aiming for our $3000 goal as, unfortunately, filming a high quality short film is not cheap.

We will be putting all money raised towards; equipment hire, location hire and fees, transportation, catering, post-production and props.

We are offering some really fantastic perks as a thank you for your much appreciated contributions.

story:
From the Archivist

THE LAST IN LINE is about passion. Passion for film. Passion for role-playing games. Passion for creativity. We set out to create something that is original, entertaining and gripping. If you love a good story, we think you'll be excited to help this film on the final leg of its journey to the premiere, tentatively scheduled for late September of 2018. 

  • Bombshell Studios has created dozens of short films, music videos, corporate tie-ins, industrial tutorials and promos and web-series over the last fifteen years.
  • Our first feature represents the culmination of all we've learned, the beneficiary of our intense commitment to preparation.
  • We have spent three-years developing a beautiful, moving tribute to friendship and honor. Until now it’s been entirely self-funded because we wanted to be sure we could bring to life something our backers could be proud to have their names attached. For even more information about the film and to see highlights from these phases you can visit our website at 40kilo.bombshellstudios.com.
  • With this final last step to go, post-production, your contribution would be instrumental in the completion of this remarkable journey.

The Captain Calls!

So much crunch! So much story! Gorgeous perks! The Broken Swords need you, recruit! Sign up, see the world, get cool things!

In a nutshell, we have to finish everything in post. This is where the "magic" is literally added to our film and includes:

  • visual effects, i.e. magic spells, exploding arrows
  • chroma key removal
  • musical score
  • foley
  • ADR
  • post-production sound mix
  • color correction
  • and more 

Now about that world traveling, recruit. Contribute to our campaign and participate in the making of this unique fantasy world.  We've got some wonderful perks all related to the film. Some were actually used in the film, some are related through the role-playing influence and others were specifically created for our funding campaign!

 

  • Actual props from the film, including the Samada skull created by our fantastic SFX guru, Alex Finegan.
  • NEW PHOTOS: 3D designs from the one-of-a-kind chess set also by Alex Finegan.
  • Special thanks in the credits and an IMDb credit on the film's IMDb page.
  • A unique campaign supplement for your table top roleplaying game of choice based in the world of The Broken Swords.
  • Posters and collectible trading cards.
  • Blu-ray, DVD or online film access.
  • Necklaces using the Ogham language (see more about that in our pitch video) created by our props goddess (and professional jeweler) Ann Marie Crosmun.
  • Biggest of all is you can become an Executive Producer on the film which gives you a title credit in the films credits and on the official poster.

So where does all the loot go? How is your contribution going to help? Check out the handy pie-chart we cooked up to shed a little light on where it gets utilized. 

The Unit

A crack team of amazing artists have been part of this journey, actors and crew who have been instrumental in getting us to where we are today. 

Joining us for this final post-production part of the journey are some massively talented folks:

  • Solomon Nero, Adam Clairmont and the amazing team at Overit Studios.
  • Zac Bennett Campbell is creating a terrific score.
  • Amazing music from Unleash the Archers.

Risks & Challenges

With any artistic endeavor there is always the risk the project doesn't get completed. But with our film we have gone to great lengths to minimize the potential of this happening.  

  • First and foremost, nearly two-thirds of the work to complete the film has already been done in the pre-production an production phases.
  • All we have left are the finishing flourishes!

Sign Up or Help Out in Other Ways

We completely understand you may not be able to contribute right now. That's perfectly fine. If you like our campaign consider sharing the information with anyone who you think may be interested. Having their names on the film could be the perfect gift for fantasy film lovers! And Indiegogo even has some great share tools that can help you do this! 

So strap on your rucksacks and head out into the night with The Broken Swords. We are very thankful for everyone who joins us on this campaign.

All photos from the cast, crew and Jason Vail Photography.

story:
Synopsis


A cinematic and visual film, Roman looks back on his most cherished memories with Polly but all are tainted by the day he lost her.

Roman doesn't know how to deal with the guilt of letting Polly into his dark, drug infested world and starts to suffer from hallucinations. He struggles to tell real life apart from his delirium eventually failing Polly, but does he have blood on his hands?


Crew


We are an all female head of department crew!

We are in our final year at Birmingham City University where we study Film Production Technology Bsc. We will be graded on this film and it will also be part of our showreel so we aim to make this film the best that it can be!


Where Will The Money Go


As we are at university, we have access to an amazing array of camera, sound and lighting equipment as well as a great studio we can use for our interior scenes, however, due to the nature of the script, we would need to branch outside of the university.

We have found an amazing composer who would love to do the music for our film however, he is asking for a small fee. Music is particularly important for the film as there is limited dialogue and we would love to have this composer's work feature on our film.

We are also hoping to enter our films into as many film festivals as possible. We are very determined individuals who would like to get our work out there and network with as many people as we can. Unfortunately, film festivals are not cheap and the cost builds up.

Furthermore, we have food and travel expenses to pay for. As most of our shoots are night shoots and we are filming in winter, it's very important we provide food and drink to keep our cast and crew warm and happy.

Even the smallest donation would help us out, whatever you can give to us would be greatly appreciated! We are so excited for this film and can't wait to start shooting in February!

story:
Friends of The Rio... UPDATE! We've been given more time! Our new deadline is April 16th! We hope to get as close as we can to our $1 million campaign goal but do not fear we can still buy the property raising funds through investors. Failure is NOT an option! WE CAN DO THIS!   

The Rio Theatre needs your help! Recent zoning changes have attracted the attention of developers who want to buy The Rio and tear it down for a new development project that would leave a big cavernous hole on the corner of Commercial and Broadway for years, and there is only one way to stop them: We have to buy The Rio!

To do that, we need to raise a $3 million down payment: we hope to do that with $1 million from donors like you, plus $2 million from private investors.

We can do this! The Rio has overcome adversity before with the huge support of the community. Our accepted offer to purchase the property was supported by over 22,000 signatures collected in just five days.

The Rio Theatre is one of the last remaining indie theatres in Vancouver. With the community’s support to change the liquor laws in 2012 The Rio is now an award winning, successful business, a live performance venue/single-screen cinema that is thriving and leading the way as a model for other independent theatres to succeed.

The Rio is located at Commercial and Broadway which is a central transit station in the heart of East Vancouver. Recent zoning changes led the property owners of the historical art-deco cinema to put it up for sale. To stop developers from giving it the same fate as other beloved cultural institutions in the city, we need to take action!

We now have until midnight on April 16th to raise the funds for the down payment, so that we can secure a mortgage and finalize the purchase of the property.

Yes! The Rio is no stranger to overcoming adversity, and East Van is not afraid of a fight. In 2012, with a groundswell of sustained community support, we won a very public battle with the LCLB to change the liquor laws to allow movie theatres to serve alcohol. Our victory in this public battle led to modernization of outdated liquor laws for the entire province of B.C.

In January 2013, Corinne Lea, owner operator of the Rio Theatre business, who led the battle to change the BC liquor laws, received the Diamond Jubilee Governor General's Award from the Queen. 

Failure is not an option. Although the Rio holds a lease for the next three years, with an option to renew, failure to purchase the building will put The Rio in the hands of developers, leaving our future uncertain.

We need to raise a $3 million down payment. We hope to do this with $1 million from donors like you through this crowdfunding campaign — if most of the 22,000 people who signed the petition gave just $100 each, we would easily meet and exceed our goal. We are looking to raise another $2 million from private investors. In addition, Corinne Lea, owner operator of The Rio business, will be taking on the mortgage and is investing her own personal funds to help make this happen.

100% of your donation will go toward buying the property, 25% will go directly to The Rio business (Shameless Lee Productions Ltd.) to cover the costs of the purchase and the costs of this campaign. The other 75% will be donated to, The Vancouver Art House Society, a registered non-profit B.C. Society that will invest the donated funds to purchase the property and become an equity shareholder of the real estate. Run by a board of industry professionals, this society was created to ensure that funds raised by your donation will not only help save the Rio but it will continue on as a legacy project to help other Vancouver arts and culture organizations in the future. If you want 100% of your donation to go directly to the Art House Society there is an option you can choose in the list of perks. All funds donated to the non-profit Society will go towards purchasing shares of the property. The non-profit Society and the private investors are all shareholders of the property, they will not be involved with the daily operations running the theatre, instead they will become the new property owners!     

The Vancouver Art House Society 

A registered non-profit B.C. Society with a mandate to help save Arts and Culture spaces in Vancouver. Run by a board of industry professionals, this Society was created to ensure that funds raised by your donation will not only help save the Rio, but it will continue on as a legacy project to help other Vancouver arts and culture organizations in the future. https://www.facebook.com/VanArtHouseSociety/

Board Members: (We are currently in the process of building a dynamic team of local board members but here's the founding crew)

Corinne Lea :  The Founder, CEO of The Rio Theatre. Corinne is an artist, entrepreneur and producer who has founded several successful, arts and cultural businesses in Vancouver such as: Flux Studios, Havana Restaurant Gallery & Theatre, Scout Boutique & Gallery and since 2008 she has owned and operated The Rio Theatre as Shameless Lee Productions, adding Xcalibur Film Productions in 2014 to the list.  In January 2012 Corinne Lea became well known for her very public battle, waged against The Liquor Control and Licensing Branch, in an effort to change the BC liquor laws that prevented movie theatres from obtaining a liquor license. In April 2012 the battle was successful and they managed to get the BC Government Liquor laws changed for the entire Province which enabled movie theatres to serve alcohol. This was a major win for Independent theatres throughout B.C. 

In January 2013 Corinne Lea received the Diamond Jubilee Governor Generals Award from the Queen. Essentially, she was awarded a medal from the government for fighting the government! She has over twenty years experience producing and promoting live multi-media shows and events. Working directly with distributors in the Film Industry, she heads a team of programmers who are responsible for The Rio Theatre’s diverse and award winning programming. She has two degrees: a BFA from Emily Carr Institute and a BA of Education from Simon Fraser University.

David Duprey:  Is passionate about offering Vancouverites eclectic spaces, places for food and drink, dance, art and music rife with character and history.  His businesses encourage people to unshackle themselves and let their creativity run wild. All of our projects are a little left of centre. David Duprey believes that remarkable things happen when creative-minded people join forces to forge new-fangled artistic paths. With four live music venues, five art galleries, two restaurants, one bar/lounge, a music festival and an abundance of affordable studio space for hundreds of working artists now under our belt, his journey is just beginning. Raised in Vancouver David loves the way this city continues to evolve and grow. It is our mission to give agency to this grassroots artistic movement in Vancouver. We take pride in maintaining the architectural integrity of this city through refurbishment and reinvention. http://randdinc.ca/past.html

Michael Wiebe:  Vancouver Park Board Commissioner , Owner of eight 1/2 restaurant lounge, MPBIA Co-president, Portside Pub Corporate Food Manager, & passionate Vancouverite. Commissioner Wiebe grew up skating on Jericho Pond, swimming at English Bay, and cycling in Stanley Park. He’s now a local business owner and community leader who wants to enhance Vancouver’s parks and facilities. Commissioner Wiebe mapped out the wheelchair accessibility of all trails in Stanley Park when he was only 12 years old and later co-founded the Vancouver Lifeguard Association. With a degree in business administration, he worked for the provincial government before opening his own restaurant, Eight 1/2, based on sustainable principles, including zero waste. Commissioner Wiebe is a director of the Mount Pleasant Business Improvement Area and a leader in zero waste, and has spoken internationally. A resident of Mount Pleasant, Commissioner Wiebe wants to help ensure that the right decisions are being made for Vancouver’s parks, guided by evidence-based policy and the principles of sustainability. He is also very passionate about saving arts and culture venues in Vancouver.

News update The Hollywood Arts Foundation joins force with The Vancouver Art House Society to offer tax receipts for larger donations!

It turns out, The Hollywood Arts Foundation also shares our goal, to help save Arts and culture venues in Vancouver. So we have decided to join forces! Not only will we be stronger together but the other major benefit this merge can offer is a tax receipt for all donations made to the Charitable Foundation and in return The Hollywood Arts Foundation will also become a shareholder in the property just like the, The Vancouver Art House Society.   

The Hollywood Arts Foundation was created in 2016 by members of the Save the Hollywood Theatre Coalition in order to save arts and cultural venues in Vancouver. The loss of theatres, movie houses, bookstores, music institutions and other cultural businesses has accelerated in the last decade, under the pressure of real estate development. We feel that culture is an invaluable resource for a positive future in our city. It is the element through which we can better understand each other, how we can live together and make our city our home. The Hollywood Arts Foundation is dedicated to helping arts and cultural organizations and venues to thrive in Vancouver.

hollywoodartsfoundation@gmail.com

www.facebook.com/VancouverHollywoodFoundation/

 

1. DONATE. Choose a perk, or donate any amount by clicking the "Back It" button with the amount you wish to contribute. New perks will be added throughout the campaign! Plus EVERYONE who donates (unless you wish to remain anonymous) will get their name on our,      "I Saved The Rio", wall of fame that will be played on our big screen during our pre-show reel!

Included in our perks is a special, I Saved The Rio Membership, card that not only gives you perks at the Rio but it also gives you discounts at local restaurants before or after the show such as Storm Crow, Chambar, JamJar, Bandidas, Eight & 1/2, Commercial Street Cafe and the list is growing everyday! 

2. INVEST. Those who wish to invest  $25,000 or more can become equity shareholders in The Rio property as long as you qualify as a friend, family, or an accredited investor. To choose this option, contact Corinne Lea directly for more information at corinne@riotheatre.ca 

3. SPREAD THE WORD. Even if you are unable to donate or invest, you can help by sharing this campaign on social media and through personal contacts.

4. COME TO OUR EVENTS. We are planning a few awesome fundraising events that we will announce soon! To see our full schedule, visit www.riotheatre.ca 

Saving The Rio is not only important to me – it’s important to the culture of Vancouver and all the indie filmmakers and live performers who share their art with the community. The Rio Theatre is “an experience you can’t download” – that we share together and these communal experiences make all our lives richer. We cannot lose this important cultural landmark!  

Thank you,  Corinne Lea 

https://globalnews.ca/news/4010500/director-kev...

https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/british-co...

What if we don't raise the money by the deadline? We are confident we can raise the money we need by April 16, 2018. But if we do not reach our $1 million goal from crowdfunding, we can still  raise the funds through investors and buy the property! That is why we have set this as a flexible goal. However if we are not able to purchase the property, all donated funds raised will be returned and The Rio Theatre business will continue to operate for the remainder of our lease. 

Can I donate a perk? Yes! Please email us at corinne@riotheatre.ca

More questions? Send us an email!

"The Rio is East Van culture. Please save it" — Roy Abraham

"It’s a part of Vancouver that cannot be replaced. There’s nowhere else in the city like it." — Natalie Bruneau

"The Rio is where I go when everything else in my life has fallen apart. It's always there for you, doors open and heart even wider." — Ben Taylor

"It’s where James Franco had seen “The Room” and then he created “The Disaster Artist” adaptation and I saw “The Disaster Artist” in the Rio and it was a really good feeling." - Nick Martinez

Kevin Smith, to Global News: “It’s a shame that some of the art houses have gone the way of the dinosaur,” he said. “This is one that’s still around and still functioning. If we can do anything to bring attention and keep those doors open, that would be a positive thing.” Smith said his fondest memory of the Rio was recording an episode of his podcast there in front of a live audience. He said he is willing to perform there again to raise money and awareness. He added that he’ll do whatever else he can to save the venerable East Van theatre, even if it means “trying to literally hold the doors open with my body, my large body. If that’s how I keep the Rio open, by keeping my body in the doorway, I’ll do it.” — Kevin Smith

"It's one of my favourite theatres and has the best lineup to watch as often you can't find the Rio's screenings anywhere else." — Lucas Rojen

"The Rio is a gathering place that connects music, theatre, art and film in Vancouver. One of the only places left with independent heart and spirit. In East Vancouver, it seems to be the only venue left that maintains diverse programming. A huge community landmark! " — Andrea Chlebak

"The Rio is a fantastic and unique environment. A crucial feature of Commercial Drive and Vancouver communities, this theatre has inspired both filmmakers and viewers in ways that franchised theatres could never. Without its influence, Vancouver's cinematic legacy would not exist. Personally, this theater is my favourite thing about Vancouver, as its space allows viewers to escape the mundane and enter a welcoming and interactive space. Giving life to performances, festivals, fandoms, and independent movies, displacing this establishment would be a terrible mistake. Its influence to Vancouver can not be understated. Let the Rio live on and continue to group the ostracized and inspire creative freedom." — Brenna McCabe

"The Rio isn’t just ‘a Theatre’. It is a symbol of character and diversity in a city that seems to not value its preservation while approving all of these redevelopment plans. Every time I’ve gone to this venue, it has been for a completely unique experience: a Greenpeace documentary, a comedy show, puppeteer DJs, human DJs, costumed 80s movie viewing, the Academy Awards. In a city crying for arts venues, this one provides.” — Janine M./Canadianish

 

Thank you to our amazing supporters and those who donated perks!
story_txt: Friends of The Rio... UPDATE! We've been given more time! Our new deadline is April 16th! We hope to get as close as we can to our $1 million campaign goal but do not fear we can still buy the property raising funds through investors. Failure is NOT an option! WE CAN DO THIS!   The Rio Theatre needs your help! Recent zoning changes have attracted the attention of developers who want to buy The Rio and tear it down for a new development project that would leave a big cavernous hole on the corner of Commercial and Broadway for years, and there is only one way to stop them: We have to buy The Rio!To do that, we need to raise a $3 million down payment: we hope to do that with $1 million from donors like you, plus $2 million from private investors.We can do this! The Rio has overcome adversity before with the huge support of the community. Our accepted offer to purchase the property was supported by over 22,000 signatures collected in just five days.The Rio Theatre is one of the last remaining indie theatres in Vancouver. With the community’s support to change the liquor laws in 2012 The Rio is now an award winning, successful business, a live performance venue/single-screen cinema that is thriving and leading the way as a model for other independent theatres to succeed.The Rio is located at Commercial and Broadway which is a central transit station in the heart of East Vancouver. Recent zoning changes led the property owners of the historical art-deco cinema to put it up for sale. To stop developers from giving it the same fate as other beloved cultural institutions in the city, we need to take action!We now have until midnight on April 16th to raise the funds for the down payment, so that we can secure a mortgage and finalize the purchase of the property.Yes! The Rio is no stranger to overcoming adversity, and East Van is not afraid of a fight. In 2012, with a groundswell of sustained community support, we won a very public battle with the LCLB to change the liquor laws to allow movie theatres to serve alcohol. Our victory in this public battle led to modernization of outdated liquor laws for the entire province of B.C.In January 2013, Corinne Lea, owner operator of the Rio Theatre business, who led the battle to change the BC liquor laws, received the Diamond Jubilee Governor General's Award from the Queen. Failure is not an option. Although the Rio holds a lease for the next three years, with an option to renew, failure to purchase the building will put The Rio in the hands of developers, leaving our future uncertain.We need to raise a $3 million down payment. We hope to do this with $1 million from donors like you through this crowdfunding campaign — if most of the 22,000 people who signed the petition gave just $100 each, we would easily meet and exceed our goal. We are looking to raise another $2 million from private investors. In addition, Corinne Lea, owner operator of The Rio business, will be taking on the mortgage and is investing her own personal funds to help make this happen.100% of your donation will go toward buying the property, 25% will go directly to The Rio business (Shameless Lee Productions Ltd.) to cover the costs of the purchase and the costs of this campaign. The other 75% will be donated to, The Vancouver Art House Society, a registered non-profit B.C. Society that will invest the donated funds to purchase the property and become an equity shareholder of the real estate. Run by a board of industry professionals, this society was created to ensure that funds raised by your donation will not only help save the Rio but it will continue on as a legacy project to help other Vancouver arts and culture organizations in the future. If you want 100% of your donation to go directly to the Art House Society there is an option you can choose in the list of perks. All funds donated to the non-profit Society will go towards purchasing shares of the property. The non-profit Society and the private investors are all shareholders of the property, they will not be involved with the daily operations running the theatre, instead they will become the new property owners!     The Vancouver Art House Society A registered non-profit B.C. Society with a mandate to help save Arts and Culture spaces in Vancouver. Run by a board of industry professionals, this Society was created to ensure that funds raised by your donation will not only help save the Rio, but it will continue on as a legacy project to help other Vancouver arts and culture organizations in the future. https://www.facebook.com/VanArtHouseSociety/Board Members: (We are currently in the process of building a dynamic team of local board members but here's the founding crew)Corinne Lea :  The Founder, CEO of The Rio Theatre. Corinne is an artist, entrepreneur and producer who has founded several successful, arts and cultural businesses in Vancouver such as: Flux Studios, Havana Restaurant Gallery & Theatre, Scout Boutique & Gallery and since 2008 she has owned and operated The Rio Theatre as Shameless Lee Productions, adding Xcalibur Film Productions in 2014 to the list.  In January 2012 Corinne Lea became well known for her very public battle, waged against The Liquor Control and Licensing Branch, in an effort to change the BC liquor laws that prevented movie theatres from obtaining a liquor license. In April 2012 the battle was successful and they managed to get the BC Government Liquor laws changed for the entire Province which enabled movie theatres to serve alcohol. This was a major win for Independent theatres throughout B.C. In January 2013 Corinne Lea received the Diamond Jubilee Governor Generals Award from the Queen. Essentially, she was awarded a medal from the government for fighting the government! She has over twenty years experience producing and promoting live multi-media shows and events. Working directly with distributors in the Film Industry, she heads a team of programmers who are responsible for The Rio Theatre’s diverse and award winning programming. She has two degrees: a BFA from Emily Carr Institute and a BA of Education from Simon Fraser University.David Duprey:  Is passionate about offering Vancouverites eclectic spaces, places for food and drink, dance, art and music rife with character and history.  His businesses encourage people to unshackle themselves and let their creativity run wild. All of our projects are a little left of centre. David Duprey believes that remarkable things happen when creative-minded people join forces to forge new-fangled artistic paths. With four live music venues, five art galleries, two restaurants, one bar/lounge, a music festival and an abundance of affordable studio space for hundreds of working artists now under our belt, his journey is just beginning. Raised in Vancouver David loves the way this city continues to evolve and grow. It is our mission to give agency to this grassroots artistic movement in Vancouver. We take pride in maintaining the architectural integrity of this city through refurbishment and reinvention. http://randdinc.ca/past.htmlMichael Wiebe:  Vancouver Park Board Commissioner , Owner of eight 1/2 restaurant lounge, MPBIA Co-president, Portside Pub Corporate Food Manager, & passionate Vancouverite. Commissioner Wiebe grew up skating on Jericho Pond, swimming at English Bay, and cycling in Stanley Park. He’s now a local business owner and community leader who wants to enhance Vancouver’s parks and facilities. Commissioner Wiebe mapped out the wheelchair accessibility of all trails in Stanley Park when he was only 12 years old and later co-founded the Vancouver Lifeguard Association. With a degree in business administration, he worked for the provincial government before opening his own restaurant, Eight 1/2, based on sustainable principles, including zero waste. Commissioner Wiebe is a director of the Mount Pleasant Business Improvement Area and a leader in zero waste, and has spoken internationally. A resident of Mount Pleasant, Commissioner Wiebe wants to help ensure that the right decisions are being made for Vancouver’s parks, guided by evidence-based policy and the principles of sustainability. He is also very passionate about saving arts and culture venues in Vancouver.News update The Hollywood Arts Foundation joins force with The Vancouver Art House Society to offer tax receipts for larger donations!It turns out, The Hollywood Arts Foundation also shares our goal, to help save Arts and culture venues in Vancouver. So we have decided to join forces! The loss of theatres, movie houses, bookstores, music institutions and other cultural businesses has accelerated in the last decade, under the pressure of real estate development. We feel that culture is an invaluable resource for a positive future in our city. It is the element through which we can better understand each other, how we can live together and make our city our home. The Hollywood Arts Foundation is dedicated to helping arts and cultural organizations and venues to thrive in Vancouver.hollywoodartsfoundation@gmail.comwww.facebook.com/VancouverHollywoodFoundation/ 1. story:
Kids in Camden need inspiration – a lens to the beauty and magic of everyday life, especially in a tough city where people like you are working – community by community – to create a brighter future.

Haiku poet Nick Virgilio was one of those Camden kids. Word by word, he wrote his way onto the world stage. Now, to honor his commitment to giving back to kids -  to spark their creativity, to foster literacy and to fuel appreciation of beauty in the darndest places - the Nick Virgilio Haiku Association needs to raise $6000.

We have built a Writers House where kids like Nick can find inspiration. Now we’re ready to re-stage and film the original play “Nick of Time... Nick of Time” written by Camden native the award winning New Jersey playwright and founding producing artistic director of South Camden Theatre Company, Joseph M. Paprzycki. The play probes the roots of Virgilio’s writing. What spurred him to draw such beauty and universal connection from nature and from his personal loss? His short form verses brought others all the way into the poet’s realm.

To make the new production of this play part of the inspirational programming at the Writers House, we need your help. With the money we are raising, we will complete a dynamic documentary film that intersperses footage of the new production with images to enrich the play. With the help of board members and corporate contribution, we have already been able to stage the play produced by board member Henry Brann, directed by John Doyle of Iron Age Theatre, filmed by Marc Brodzik of Woodshop Films and Andrew Geller, featuring actors Bob Weick, Rocky Wilson and Ned Pryce.  

The film is slated to premiere at the Haiku North America Conference in Santa Fe which has accepted it for screening in September 2017. Then the film will become a key element of programming at the Nick Virgilio Writers House, Camden, NJ, when it opens later this year. It will be featured there along with a previous documentary by Sean Dougherty called "remembering Nick Virgilio."

The people behind this project are a small 501c3, the Nick Virgilio Haiku Association. We welcome additional board members with passion for progress. We particularly seek people with skills in the creative and professional arts and with fundraising  background. The organization has amassed quite a track record over our 28 years, operating haiku workshops for educators and kids, creating works of theatre and film in support of teaching poetry, operating the annual Nick Virgilio Haiku Competition sponsored by the Haiku Society of America that now draws more than 3,000 entries annually from around the globe, and partnering with Rutgers University on digitizing the Virgilio archives. 

Again, there are many ways you can help:

  • Contribute funds to help with our mission 
  • Contribute your passion and expertise: join our Board
  • Contribute your energy - engage with committees making new programming
  • Help with grant writing - NVHA seeks experienced grantwriters
  • Donate an up to date computer to the NVHA office 

This IndieGoGo account is linked directly to the non-profit Nick Virgilio Haiku Association and all funds raised here will go directly there, earmarked for this endeavor. For other contribution opportunities, to buy books of Virgilio’s haiku or to learn more, visit www.nickvirgiliohaiku.org  The Nick Virgilio Writers House joins the burgeoning Waterfront South Arts District in Camden which includes the Camden FireWorks art collaborative and studios, the Camden Shipyard & Maritime Museum, the South Camden Theatre Company, Brigid's House, the Michael J. Doyle Fieldhouse, the Poet's Walk, and the Center for Environmental Transformation.

Watch for the upcoming story in the Courier-Post about this! We'll post a link here when it runs.

By funding our project, you’re saying you care about inspiring (and aspiring) writers, you care about kids, you care about literacy and you care about building community resources in places in need. Thanks for helping.

story:
Me:

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • I'm Ryan Darnell and I'm a director, screenwriter and cinematographer. I have been working on student and independent films for the past 3 years.
  • Contributors will help us to fund crucial elements of the production such as hiring crew, actors, equipment, renting locations, transport, paying for food, props and costumes.

What We Need & Perks:

  • We have broken down our budget and it comes to just over €1000.
  • This will be divided as already said between crew, actors, music, distribution, etc.

Perks:

  • €5 - Digital Poster
  • €10 - Link to Film
  • €20 - Digital Package
  • €35 - Signed Script
  • €50 - Signed Poster
  • €75 - Private Screening + Physical Copy of the Film
  • €100 - Executive Producer Credit

The Impact:

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Challenges:

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help:

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary

A retired Kong Fu Master Lao Zhang(45), overprotecting his son Dragon(10) always stops his son try new things. His uncle Jack gives him a skateboard, which is stolen by gangster and makes Dragon gets hurt. Because Lao Zhang’s indifferent, Dragon is so disappointed with his father. Eventually, Lao Zhang beats the gangsters, and wins his son back.   

What We Need & What You Get

 

  • Our gola is $5000, this money will spend on
  • Stunts
  • Post production,
  • Sound Mixing.
  • Hair & Make up
  • Production Design

The Impact

 

This film create by over 17 potential further film makers.

Majority of crew are Vancouver film school, who had professional training.

Our action Director is a Famous Marital Art Tai Chi Master – Gao Fen.

Our stunt Coordinator is – Gavin buhr.

中文简介

我们是谁？
我们是一群年轻的中国电影人 我们不远万里来到异国学习电影 为了可以做出更高水准更能代表中国的作品 为了这个作品我们组成了17人的团队 近半年的筹备 只为了能做出一个可以讲述中国哲学的电影 和我们年轻人对中国传统武术的看法

温哥华电影学院
学校坐落在被称为「北美好莱坞的温哥华」在权威世界大学排名机构QS对外公布的2015年世界顶尖电影学院排名中，评选温哥华电影学院（Vancouver Film School）为加拿大影视教育的领头人，是该地区最好的电影学院之一大部分的热门电影都可以看到VFS毕业生的身影

关于我们的电影「刀客」
本片讲述了一个武术大师老张 为了照顾没有自理能力的儿子大龙只身来到外国 藏身于餐馆做了一个大厨 平静的生活被一系列的意外打乱 迫使他拿起武器为儿子而战

我们为何而战？
现今，全球越来越多人开始唱衰中国武术存在的必要性。尽管与国土相隔千万里的距离，我们仍然感觉到有一种应当做什么的，可谓称之是使命感的召唤。众人质疑和蔑视声越甚，我们心中气焰越高。从小在中国文化下熏陶长大的我们，又同时是一群年轻的电影人，我们决定用我们最为擅长的镜头去做出对消极声音的回击。
何为武术？ 武字是由止和戈组成，日复一日的练习是为了捍卫自己，而不是引起争端，正如我们的原意，愿以此作品为化干戈而玉帛的精神贡献自己的一份忠诚。对善意的建议我们愿用此片去丰盈对方的看法，而面对恶意的攻击，我们会用它证明，文化与传承存在的必要意义。
我们是一群年轻的电影人，我们也是一群有梦想，力气充沛，想要对世界释放更多能量和善意的人。
但与此同时，形影单只的我们需要更多的力量来充裕这个为中国文化发声的梦想。


电影将会在本年九月份开拍 本年十二月底结束制作投放电影节
您的支持会得到我们在片尾以字幕形式的鸣谢
大额支持会得到我们以赞助商的形式在片尾出现
您的支持会得到我们以官方文件的方式得以确认
我们已经准备好打响这场战役了 请和我们站在一起
story_txt:
Short Summary
A retired Kong Fu Master Lao Zhang(45), overprotecting his son Dragon(10) always stops his son try new things. His uncle Jack gives him a skateboard, which is stolen by gangster and makes Dragon gets hurt. Because Lao Zhang’s indifferent, Dragon is so disappointed with his father. Eventually, Lao Zhang beats the gangsters, and wins his son back.   

What We Need & What You Get
 

Our gola is $5000, this money will spend on
Stunts
Post production,
Sound Mixing.
Hair & Make up
Production Design


The Impact
 
This film create by over 17 potential further film makers.
Majority of crew are Vancouver film school, who had professional training.
Our action Director is a Famous Marital Art Tai Chi Master – Gao Fen.
Our stunt Coordinator is – Gavin buhr.

story:
On August 21st, 2017, the moon will pass between the Sun and the Earth, casting a shadow across America's heartland, in what will be America's most significant solar eclipse in more than 80 years. For those who are passionate about witnessing this event, in order to see the eclipse in totality, you have to be in the right spot. The path of the shadow is a long one, but it is also narrow, meaning most people will have to travel great distances to see it.

In the interest of sharing this celestial event with the rest of the world in a way that has never been done before, we are creating a fictional narrative that unfolds in real time, live during the solar eclipse.

…and the live stream will be available to the world for free.

The Story

Western Sol tells the story of an honest and poor rancher, James Avery, who is coerced by a brood of outlaws into robbing a bank for them. The outlaws, led by an intelligent and sinister Davey Collins, lead Avery into town, where they all spread out to keep an eye on him. Feeling like he has no choice, Avery reluctantly agrees to follow through with the plan. But will he do it? Or will an opportunity arise to turn the tables on the outlaws?


Technically Speaking…

There are a few challenges to overcome here, so let's review the requirements:

  • Western story
  • Period-accurate representation
  • Real-time performances and execution
  • In the geographic path of the eclipse
  • Live streamed to the web

So, how do we do this? A period-accurate western has its challenges, such as making sure props and attire are correct. This is the work of a great costumer and propmaster. We have an excellent pair of armorers attached to the project that, in addition to providing professional firearms safety supervision, are also providing period-accurate single-action revolvers and long guns and blank rounds.

In order to pull this off in real-time, we are treating this like a theatrical production. Using our background in theater and live television, as well as our experience in cinematic "oners" (pronounced won-erh), also known as a long take, we are carefully choreographing the camera and actors' blocking and timing for the entire piece. Our intent is to shoot the entire film as a oner, however we may end up breaking it up into more shots, depending on a few factors. The actors will receive direction and timing updates from the director via hidden wireless IFB earpieces, and if adjustments need to be made, they can do so without interrupting the show.

The path of the moon's shadow is very specific, and it's narrower than the layman might think. It's also very scientifically predictable, down to the exact latitude/longitude minutes and seconds, and the time-of-day millisecond. Our filming location is already locked, and it is a replica 19th century western town with a livery, bank, hotel, church, and of course, a saloon. It also happens to be almost dead-center in the path of totality, meaning, from this location, we will have a full, total eclipse, and the duration of that eclipse will be fairly long. The location truly is perfect for this project.

In order to live-stream this performance, there is a decent technological hurdle to jump: bandwidth. We are on a small ranch in the middle of Wyoming… while there is internet access, it's not really there for this type of thing. Can you imagine if we line all this up to go live, and the stream cuts out, or is of such low resolution that you can barely see it? To overcome this, we will bring a satellite truck and operator to the ranch. This will give us a high-bandwidth upload connection, as we beam our signal into space, where it will be relayed back down to a studio in Utah, then uploaded to the web. The latency on this type of upload will be approximately 15 seconds, which is pretty good. The satellite truck is already booked and committed-to, which is huge, considering the high demand for these trucks on this day.


Where does the money go?

Frankly, short films do not usually cost this much money. Other than the standard expenses, there are a few factors that are working against us in regards to the budget.

  • During the eclipse, all nearby hotels are mostly booked, and very costly. The alternative is to rent campers and have them on-site.
  • Live-streaming requires a satellite truck, and the rental of the satellite
  • Rehearsals take up additional time, which means more crew and longer equipment rentals
  • Given the live broadcast nature, we need to provide various redundancies, to ensure our success, even if there is technical failure.

Live productions are inherently more expensive than your typical short film, and this is no different. Our budget is designed in a way that allows us to execute a version of this film with the IndieGoGo goal that we have set, but in reality, this is only meant to be partial funding. The more money we can raise, either through over-funding on IGG, or through marketing sponsorships, the more excellently we can execute this production. We have passed our go/no-go point already, so we will be filming Western Sol regardless of how much money we raise here. The funds raised here will allow us to pay our crew better wages, and to help us avoid going broke in the process ;-).

story:
Thank you for visiting my Indiegogo campaign!

 

Hey everyone,

I am a Computer Animation major at the School of Visual Arts, and I am currently mid-production on my senior thesis film, Yuanfen. This film is not only a culmination of my four years of education and hard work, but it is also an expression of a topic that means a great deal to me.

I never imagined I would have the opportunity to bring my story to life while leading a team of 20 incredible artists, which is why I need all of your help in funding the rest of this production. 

3D Character Render

 

With your help...

Your donation will allow me to hire the extremely talented, award-nominated composer, Jerome Leroy, to compose an original soundtrack for my film. 

  • $1,000 -- COMPOSER FEE
  • $2,500 -- ORCHESTRA/MUSICIANS

TOTAL: $3,500

 

Jian & Panda Style Frame

 

Directing and producing this film has been a true labor of love, but I need some extra help to make it the absolute best it can be. Whether it's a monetary donation small or big, or simply sharing my project with those you know, I am grateful for any contribution you can make. 

 

Thank you so much! I can't wait to share my story with you. 

-Amanda

story:
Did you know that according to THEFIRE.ORG, 66% of all college or university students have had colleges revoke part or some of their free speech rights? That's your first amendment that the founding fathers put in there to protect you. 

HOW IS THAT POSSIBLE?

Well, I, Josh Eisenberg, as part of my Master's Thesis am making a documentary to find out how this is possible, when it's happened, why it's happened and most of all where it's happened in a documentary road trip across the country. 

I will travel to schools that have a history of protests and riots to find out who was wrong who was right, and most of all I will ask the hard questions like, can a school actually revoke your diploma for using your first amendment rights in a way that they frown upon?

Frankly I don't know all the answers and I am not going to until this film gets made. 

Places I plan on going:

- Columbia University

- Cal Berkeley

- Ole Miss University

- Jackson State University

- Kent State, Ohio

- Harvard University

- Princeton, University

- Towson University (Maryland)
 

BUT I CAN ONLY DO IT WITH YOUR HELP!

I am asking you the viewer to help me. I want you to produce this thing with me by being a crowd funder. 

Every morsel that is made towards this film will go towards travel to places where I can shoot, equipment rental or getting crew. 

I will not rest until all the answers are had an I have a film made by hopefully this late Spring/Early Summer 2018. 

 

Please donate. Anything you can do to help will go a long way.  At minimum by donating you will get your name in the credits and make a difference.

story:
Sweet Like Poison is about a 16 year old girl named Dolly. She looks very young for her age which makes people perceive her as innocent and naive. She is shy but also has her own individual style that doesn't quite conform to the trends. All of this mixed together makes her classmates view her as a weirdo which leads them to exclude, ignore and bully her.  Dolly's loneliness leads her to create vivid and twisted fantasies which usually involve murder. When Dolly is the only one not invited to a party she decides enough is enough, it's time to turn her fantasies into reality. However, once she is finally let in, she finds herself having an unintentional heart to heart with the ones who are the most cruel to her and they realise they have more in common than they thought (minus the whole murderer thing) they all start enjoying themselves and for the first time Dolly is accepted - but it’s too late, her new friends have all eaten the poisoned cupcakes she made for them and they begin to die around her. Dolly is left alone once more.

This film mixes stereotypically feminine and pastel pink visuals with dark and often gruesome situations.

We are aiming to raise £1000 for our short film. It's an ambitious target but we believe we can smash it! Here is what the money is going towards: 

Locations: 

We are already lucky enough to have secured one location, Worthing College, but we are still on the look out for a beautiful vintage style house we can use for our interior scenes. 

 

Actors:

Student projects never have a big budget which has lead to them being notorious for not paying their actors. We want to change this. The majority of the money raised in our crowdfunding campaign will go towards paying our three amazingly talented actors.

 

Production Design:

We are creating  surreal, pastel pink visuals which means we are relying on production design to turn our locations into this world. This does not come cheap so a lot of our budget will be going towards this. 

 

Special Effects:

Our opening scene takes place in a bath full of blood and this is more expensive to create than you might initially think. There are a number of other gorey scenes which will require special effects as well. It's important that we do these right so the film looks as polished and professional as we know it should. 

 

Festivals:

This film is our calling card as we enter the industry and we want to make our mark in the film festival circuit. This doesn't come cheap so money from our crowdfunding campaign will be going towards festival submissions.

 

We have many incentives to offer to say thank you for your contribution. A donation of more than £10 will secure your name in the credits and there's also the chance to receive exclusive behind the scenes videos, to see the film before anyone else and even to spend the day on set!

 

Writer/Director - Beth Bayes

Beth began her life as a performer and always saw herself in front of the camera, but creating her first film in college started her love for making films. Beth has always loved horror and thriller films but she also loves anything cute so she is excited to mix these two things together. 

 

Producer - Tanya Patel 

During Tanya's three years at Brighton Film School she has taken on many technical roles but  found her niche in the role of producer by the second year. Within film school she has produced many short films in different genre of films apart from Horror and this is why she is excited to take on "Sweet Like Poison".

1st AD - Bethany Tucker

Bethany has lots of experience working as a 1st AD on numerous short films as well as producing an independent feature film called "The Holiday" last year. After hearing "other Beth" as we call each other, talk about her script for the first time, this Beth instantly knew she wanted to work on the film and after watching other Beth’s previous work she couldn’t wait to jump onto the project. 

DOP - Brad James 

Brad James is the Director of Photography on Sweet Like Poison. He studied for 4 years in Bedford where he is from before moving to Brighton for his final year. He took on the project after really enjoying the script and the characters. He feels feels this film has a unique and interesting style which is what he is looking to show.

Gaffer - Brandon Borowski 

This is Beth and Brandon's second time working together after he was gaffer on their short film "Friend Request" in 2017. Brandon enjoys experimenting with different lighting and is excited to create Dolly's surreal world.

Sound - Harri Clements 

Harrison Clements is a Sound Designer with much experience in creating soundscapes with a focus on character and narrative. He believes Sweet Like Poison is the perfect fit for his skill set, with it's strong character driven plot.

Editor - Kodi Upton

Kodi is a Brighton based film/video editor, with experience in film trailers, narrative shorts and music performance showreels. Her love of psychological horror films such as Split & Shutter Island drew her to Sweet Like Poison.

Marc Simposon - Production Designer

 

Marc has a background in Carpentry and Design and has been involved in various creative projects over the years. From being a Set Decorator on a Feature Film to  going on tour with a band. 

Marc was interested in getting involved in this project to help raise awareness to younger people that every action you take has a consequence. Also to be aware that if someone were to treat you badly it may not be a reflection on you, but perhaps their personal insecurities or their current emotional state.

 

 

We totally understand if you can't donate, there are other ways you can help! Simply sharing this campaign and following us on our various social medias is invaluable support that we really appreciate. 

Thank you for taking the time to view our campaign and we hope you will help us achieve our goal!

Festivals:
This film is our calling card as we enter the industry and we want to make our mark in the film festival circuit. This doesn't come cheap so money from our crowdfunding campaign will be going towards festival submissions.
 

We have many incentives to offer to say thank you for your contribution. A donation of more than £10 will secure your name in the credits and there's also the chance to receive exclusive behind the scenes videos, to see the film before anyone else and even to spend the day on set!
 


Writer/Director - Beth Bayes
Beth began her life as a performer and always saw herself in front of the camera, but creating her first film in college started her love for making films. Beth has always loved horror and thriller films but she also loves anything cute so she is excited to mix these two things together. 
 
Producer - Tanya Patel 
During Tanya's three years at Brighton Film School she has taken on many technical roles but  found her niche in the role of producer by the second year. Within film school she has produced many short films in different genre of films apart from Horror and this is why she is excited to take on "Sweet Like Poison".
1st AD - Bethany Tucker
Bethany has lots of experience working as a 1st AD on numerous short films as well as producing an independent feature film called "The Holiday" last year. After hearing "other Beth" as we call each other, talk about her script for the first time, this Beth instantly knew she wanted to work on the film and after watching other Beth’s previous work she couldn’t wait to jump onto the project. 
DOP - Brad James 
Brad James is the Director of Photography on Sweet Like Poison. He studied for 4 years in Bedford where he is from before moving to Brighton for his final year. He took on the project after really enjoying the script and the characters. He feels feels this film has a unique and interesting style which is what he is looking to show.
Gaffer - Brandon Borowski 
This is Beth and Brandon's second time working together after he was gaffer on their short film "Friend Request" in 2017. Brandon enjoys experimenting with different lighting and is excited to create Dolly's surreal world.
Sound - Harri Clements 
Harrison Clements is a Sound Designer with much experience in creating soundscapes with a focus on character and narrative. He believes Sweet Like Poison is the perfect fit for his skill set, with it's strong character driven plot.
Editor - Kodi Upton
Kodi is a Brighton based film/video editor, with experience in film trailers, narrative shorts and music performance showreels. Her love of psychological horror films such as Split & Shutter Island drew her to Sweet Like Poison.
Marc Simposon - Production Designer
 
Marc has a background in Carpentry and Design and has been involved in various creative projects over the years. From being a Set Decorator on a Feature Film to  going on tour with a band. 
Marc was interested in getting involved in this project to help raise awareness to younger people that every action you take has a consequence. Also to be aware that if someone were to treat you badly it may not be a reflection on you, but perhaps their personal insecurities or their current emotional state.

 
 


We totally understand if you can't donate, there are other ways you can help! Simply sharing this campaign and following us on our various social medias is invaluable support that we really appreciate. 
Thank you for taking the time to view our campaign and we hope you will help us achieve our goal!

story:
Resumen /Summary

Comencé a escribir esta historia mientras trabajaba en un proyecto de radios comunitarias en la región caribe colombiana. Pluma verde es una propuesta arriesgada en un país donde las producciones fílmicas se han enfrascado en chistes simplistas y violencia de narcotraficantes, he dedicado algunos años de mi vida a la producción de cortometrajes y este sera el primer paso para realizar mi primera película.

He reunido un grupo talentoso de personas para formar el equipo técnico detrás de esta historia que ofrecerá entretenimiento a sus espectadores. 

I started writing this story while working on a community radio project in the Colombian Caribbean region. Pluma verde is a different proposal in a country where film productions have been engaged in simplistic jokes and violence by drug traffickers, I have dedicated some years of my life to the production of short films and this will be the first step to make my first film. I have assembled a talented group of people to form the technical team behind this story that will offer entertainment to its viewers.

Lo que necesitamos y lo que obtienes / What we need and what you get

 Una producción es costosa, pero gran parte del equipo técnico no pide pago, por eso solo necesitamos 2000 dolares que en dinero colombiano serian alrededor de 5 millones de pesos colombianos, con este dinero se cubrirán los pagos a personal extra como actores, asistentes, maquillajes y vestuario.  Se pagara la alimentación, transportes y el alquiler de locaciones. Ademas se tomara el 10% de lo recogido para cubrir las recompensas que prometemos. 

Desde el inicio de la campaña estamos llevando registro en vídeos y fotos de todas las actividades en torno a Pluma verde, queremos tener una cercanía total con nuestros mecenas, sobre todo con aquellos a quienes les interese la producción de audiovisuales, estaremos atentos a responder inquietudes por medio de nuestro correo plumaverdeoficial@gmail.com
Los 2000 dolares son nuestro presupuesto real, pero trabajaremos con lo que se recolecte.

 

A production is expensive, but a large part of the technical team does not ask for payment, so we only need 2,000 dollars that in Colombian money would be around 5 million Colombian pesos, with this money we will cover the payments to extra personnel such as actors, assistants, make-ups and wardrobe. Food, transportation and rent of leases will be paid. In addition, 10% of what was collected will be taken to cover the rewards that we promise. From the beginning of the campaign we are taking record in videos and photos of all the activities around Pluma verde, we want to have a total closeness with our patrons, especially with those who are interested in audiovisual production, we will be attentive to answer questions through our email plumaverdeoficial@gmail.com The 2000 dollars are our real budget, but we will work with what is collected.

 

Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar/ Other ways you can help

Nuestra campaña no tiene un tiempo muy extendido, pero deseamos poder realizar este gran proyecto, si llegaste hasta este punto, significa que algo te gusto, seria genial si compartes esta campaña entre tus conocidos o personas a quienes les interese aportar en la creación de nuevos proyectos, agradecemos el eco que nos ayudes a crear compartiendo la campaña. Muchas gracias.

 

Our campaign does not have a very extended time, but we want to be able to carry out this great project, if you got to this point, it means that something you like, it would be great if you share this campaign among your acquaintances or people who are interested in contributing to the creation of new projects, we appreciate the echo that you help us create by sharing the campaign. Thank you very much.

story:
About Us & Our Film

This short film was written by — and stars — Rob Walker. He directed TV movies for the BBC for years before he moved to southern Arizona, fell in love, and now has seven children. He wanted to explore a variety of compelling topics in an engaging way...and the ending is definitely a twist! 

Liz Claire Feliciano, a Pittsburgh native, has been acting, singing, and dancing all her life. With her mother and brothers playing instruments growing up, and an uncle and cousins in bands and running a music store, Liz was destined for the arts. You can find her playing the harp at various venues around Tucson. This production marks her transition from the stage to the silver screen, and she’s excited to continue making art with Rob and Avai that challenges people to think critically and grow as human beings.

Avai d'Amico, cinematographer and adventurer, moved to Tucson for the warm climate and inexpensive cost of living, but quickly fell in love with dangerous hobbies like scaling vertical cliff faces and barreling full speed toward patches of cacti while riding on only two wheels. He is the co-chair of Independent Film Arizona's documentary group. 

What We Need

We've worked hard and we want to show the world what we're capable of. Film festivals are a great way to get in front of audiences, so we want to submit our film to as many festivals as we can. The average festival submission fee is $35. Indiegogo takes 5% and their payment processing partner, Stripe, takes another 3-4%. $500 will secure our entrance to a dozen festivals. If we can get the full $1000, we'll submit to two dozen festivals!

What You Get

We truly appreciate your help getting our film out there, so we want to share something extra with you in return. Exclusive posters, signed photos, special IMDb credits, and of course be one of the first people to see our film — before it’s publicly available!

Risks & Challenges

We've already shot our movie, and we applied the knowledge gained from our previous productions to make sure this will be our best film yet! We just need a little help with funding so we can submit to many festivals, helping our film reach as wide an audience as possible.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute to this crowdfunding campaign directly, we'd appreciate you sharing it on social media. 

Thanks so much for considering our production!

story:
Short Summary

We are a group of talented artists with a hilarious story to tell. That story is Three Fucks Soomba! With your contribution and participation, we’ll be able to bring this comedy to life. It’s not always easy to produce a project when you don’t yet have that “I’d like to thank the academy” money. Yet and still we have something great we want to create and share. We want to do it justice. We want to grow as creators. We want you to be entertained. WE WANT TO RULE THE WORLD, MUAHAHAHA…ok ok let’s not make this creepy. Thank you for your help and support. We really appreciate you giving a fuck!

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need your money to help fund the equipment we need to film our project.
  • Our perks are fun, we want you to be a part of this film with us, so come in be an extra in our soomba class, or come to the screening of our film when we are done.
  • If you are unable to help us financially please spread the word and share our link so that we can get our little dream project seen by others who may be interested in learning about it.
